The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. {"id": "10053787", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 337, "label": "dmoz/Business/Consumer Goods and Services/Office Products", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Consumer_Goods_and_Services/Office_Products", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711886864", "source": {"id": "166", "title": "CBS News", "uri": "cbsnews.com"}, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/1-florida-police-officer-killed-3-others-injured-in-separate-shootings/", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. -- One police officer was killed and three wounded in nighttime shootings in two Florida cities where the officers were responding to suspected drug activity and reports of a suicide attempt, police said Saturday.\n\nOne officer was killed and another gravely injured late Friday night in Kissimmee in central Florida just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter died later in a hospital and Howard was in serious condition, O'Dell said.\n\nO'Dell said Baxter was a three-year veteran and Howard is a 10-year veteran, CBS affiliate WKMG-TV reports. Both men are husbands and fathers.\n\n\"Right now, as you can imagine, (the families) are completely heartbroken and devastated,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday about the shooting, posting \"we are with you!\"\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nThe Jacksonville Sheriff's Office (JSO) said on Twitter that two police officers were shot in the west side of the city. The officers were responding to an attempted suicide call, JSO Director Mike Bruno told CBS affiliate WJAX-TV.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted about both shootings, writing that he was \"heartbroken to hear of the loss\" of the Kissimmee officers. About Jacksonville, he wrote he was \"praying\" for the officers.\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"", {"id": "10055486", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711891852", "source": {"id": "1808", "title": "KHOU", "uri": "khou.com"}, "url": "http://www.khou.com/news/nation-world/one-police-officer-killed-three-injured-in-separate-fla-shootings/465570874", "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nKISSIMMEE, Fla. - One police officer was killed and three wounded in nighttime shootings in two Florida cities where the officers were responding to suspected drug activity and reports of a suicide attempt, police said Saturday.\n\nOne officer was killed and another gravely injured late Friday night in Kissimmee in central Florida just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nPresident Trump took to Twitter and offered his condolences, saying his \"thoughts and prayers are with the Kissimmee Police and their loved ones.\"\n\nMy thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!#LESM -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nJust learned of two @JSOPIO in danger tonight - we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida. -- Rick Scott (@FLGovScott)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\n\u00a9 2017 The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. Sgt. Sam Howard was also shot and is in grave condition, police said.\n\nThe shooting may have been an ambush, O'Dell said, as the officers responded to a suspicious activity call just before 9:30 pm Friday. Within minutes, gunfire erupted, surprising the officers, who were not able to return fire, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the Kissimmee Police Department, was pronounced dead. (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of two police officers in Florida was arrested in a bar several hours after the attack, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter, who died Friday night after the attack. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for that.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\n(Sgt. Sam Howard and Officer Matthew Baxter/Photo Courtesy: Kissimmee Police Department)\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Sam Howard was also shot during the incident and he isn't expected to make it, the chief says. Howard is in the hospital in grave condition, O'Dell said. The two officers were shot in Kissimmee, Florida late Friday night while they were patrolling the area.\n\nA second Florida police officer has died from wounds he suffered in a shooting Friday night, Kissimmee police said on its Facebook page.\n\nSgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday afternoon, a day after Officer Matthew Baxter died at the scene of a shooting in the central Florida city near Orlando.\n\nEarlier Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Everett Glenn Miller, 45, had been charged with first-degree murder in Baxter's killing.\n\nThe officers were in an area known for drug activity, and Baxter approached Miller and two other men before 9:30 p.m. Friday, the chief said. Howard came as backup. There was a scuffle and gunfire, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the Kissimmee Police Department, was pronounced dead.\n\nMiller is the only one charged of three people the police questioned, the chief said. He also faces charges of carrying a concealed weapon and resisting arrest.\n\nO'Dell said he was found at a bar and had a 9 mm pistol and a .22-caliber revolver.\n\nFollowing the news of the shooting, President Donald Trump tweeted his condolences.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. Sam Howard's passing.\"\n\nKissimmee is about 20 miles south of Orlando.\n\nTwo officers in Jacksonville were also injured Friday. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday, Aug. 19, 2017. (Kissimmee Police Department)\n\nA suspect in the fatal shooting of two police officers in Florida was arrested in a bar several hours after the attack, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter, who died Friday night after the attack. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for that.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. {"id": "10025976", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711811039", "source": {"id": "191", "title": "WMC Action News 5", "uri": "wmcactionnews5.com"}, "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36171942/1-police-officer-killed-3-injured-in-2-shootings-in-florida", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) - One police officer was killed and three wounded in nighttime shootings in two Florida cities where the officers were responding to suspected drug activity and reports of a suicide attempt, police said Saturday.\n\nOne officer was killed and another gravely injured late Friday night in Kissimmee in central Florida just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. Officials said the second officer died Saturday afternoon.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot outside a small-town store in Fairchance, south of Pittsburgh. State police say the troopers, both taken to hospitals after the Friday night shooting in Fairchance, were in stable condition.\n\nThe two Florida officers were killed late Friday night in Kissimmee, just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference Saturday that a suspect, Everett Miller, was arrested several hours after the shootings.\n\nHe faces a first-degree murder charge. Authorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nThe other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. The shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, O'Dell said earlier. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter died later in a hospital, O'Dell said. Howard died Saturday from his injuries, officials said.\n\nO'Dell said Baxter was a three-year veteran and Howard was a 10-year veteran, CBS affiliate WKMG-TV reports. Both men were husbands and fathers.\n\n\"Right now, as you can imagine, (the families) are completely heartbroken and devastated,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was later arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday about the shooting, posting \"we are with you!\"\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nThe Jacksonville Sheriff's Office (JSO) said on Twitter that two police officers were shot in the west side of the city. The officers were responding to an attempted suicide call, JSO Director Mike Bruno told CBS affiliate WJAX-TV.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted about both shootings, writing that he was \"heartbroken to hear of the loss\" of the Kissimmee officers. About Jacksonville, he wrote he was \"praying\" for the officers.\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nPolice in Pennsylvania told reporters Friday night that the encounter that injured two troopers took place outside a Stop 'n Save in Fairchance, a borough about 52 miles south of Pittsburgh. They say that as the officers approached the man, he pulled out a gun from a backpack and fired it. {"id": "10107369", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712037209", "source": {"id": "11193", "title": "Dothan Eagle", "uri": "dothaneagle.com"}, "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/national/suspect-in-killings-of-fla-officers-arrested-at-bar/article_c08987fc-2999-5a44-8899-8b72873db6d7.html", "body": "CORRECTS STATUS OF SECOND POLICE OFFICER - After placing flowers at a makeshift memorial, Miguel Velez, say's a prayer for the officer that was killed on Saturday, Aug. 19, 2017 in Kissimmee, Fla. The Kissimmee Police Department says Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday from his injuries. His colleague, Officer Matthew Baxter, died Friday night after the attack in a neighborhood of Kissimmee, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando. (Red Huber/Orlando Sentinel via AP)\n\nKISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T20:59:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 177, "textStart": 164, "date": "2017-08-19", "amb": Sam Howard was also shot and is in grave condition, police said.\n\nThe shooting may have been an ambush, O'Dell said, as the officers responded to a suspicious activity call just before 9:30 pm Friday. Within minutes, gunfire erupted, surprising the officers, who were not able to return fire, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the Kissimmee Police Department, was pronounced dead. Howard remains hospitalized.\n\nMiller is the only one charged of three people the police questioned, the chief said. When officers arrived in response to an attempted suicide call, they encountered a man armed with a high-powered rifle and exchanged gunfire, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nOne officer was struck in both hands, while the other was hit in his stomach, Bruno said. The suspect, who was also injured, died after being taken to a local hospital, he said.\n\nAnd in Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot late Friday, said Melinda Bondarenka, a spokeswoman with (AP) -- One police officer was killed and three wounded in nighttime shootings in two Florida cities where the officers were responding to suspected drug activity and reports of a suicide attempt, police said Saturday.\n\nOne officer was killed and another gravely injured late Friday night in Kissimmee in central Florida just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. The other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. Three of four suspects in the Kissimmee shooting were arrested, and the shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger, Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. The three other people in the house were safe, Bruno said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimmee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. {"id": "10129755", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712107743", "source": {"id": "4684", "title": "The Financial Express", "uri": "financialexpress.com"}, "url": "http://www.financialexpress.com/world-news/us-shootings-suspect-in-killings-of-2-florida-officers-arrested-at-bar/816014/", "body": "Sergeant Sam Howard died today afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following last night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nA police officer in Florida died from his injuries today, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar. Sergeant Sam Howard died today afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following last night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando. Officer Matthew Baxter died last night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller. Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death. During a patrol late yesterday of a neighbourhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. The officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire.\n\nThey weren't wearing body cameras. Sheriff's deputies with a neighbouring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said. They found a handgun and revolver on him. \"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said. The police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs. Authorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said today that no other arrests are anticipated. Miller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office.\n\nThe early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said. Baxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children. Howard, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said. \"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\" Separately, two other officers were injured late yesterday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach. Jacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said today that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following last night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh last night. In a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle. President Trump tweeted early today that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said. Florida Governor Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers. US Representative Darren Soto said today that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the US Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the US House to honour the {"id": "10128090", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712102559", "source": {"id": "1155", "title": "The Indian Express", "uri": "indianexpress.com"}, "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/florida-shooting-suspect-in-killings-of-two-police-officers-arrested-at-bar-4804784/", "body": "By: AP | Florida | Published:August 20, 2017 7:31 am Two law enforcement officers stand guard outside Osceola Regional Medical Center after two Kissimmee police officers were shot Friday, Aug. 18, 2017, in Kissimmee, Florida. (AP) 1 policeman killed, 3 injured in 2 shootings in FloridaOrlando shooting: At least five killed, police rule out terror angleOrlando gunman Omar Mateen was a regular at the Pulse gay club: Report\n\nA police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando. Officer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller. Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. The officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said. They found a handgun and revolver on him. \"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs. Authorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation show that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children. Howard, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said. \"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers. In Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night. In a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said. Florida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers. US Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nGov. Rick Scott on Saturday evening issued an executive order removing the case from Ayala and reassigning it. \"Today, I am using my executive authority to reassign this case to State Attorney Brad King to ensure the victims of last night's attack and their families receive the justice they deserve,\" Scott said in the order. A spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an email inquiry seeking comment.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Florida shooting", "dateTime": {"id": "10049466", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711875521", "source": {"id": "16776", "title": "bustle.com", "uri": "bustle.com"}, "url": "https://www.bustle.com/p/who-was-matthew-baxter-the-kissimmee-police-officer-was-on-the-force-for-3-years-77633", "body": "Two police officers were shot in central Florida on Friday night, and soon after, one of the officers succumbed to his injures. Kissimmee Police Officer Matthew Baxter died, while the other responding officer, Sgt. Sam Howard was in \"very grave condition\" as of around 1:30 a.m. ET early Saturday.\n\nAccording to Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell, Baxter was a three-year veteran. Local 10 News reported that he was married to a fellow police officer at the Kissimmee Police Department and had three children. \"Tonight we lost a brave officer - Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero,\" Florida Gov. Rick Scott wrote on Twitter. Sgt. Howard is also a husband and father, The Orlando Sentinel reported.\n\nBaxter and Howard responded to a call of suspicious persons in a downtown area. The shooting may have been an \"ambush,\" the chief said, and the officers did not return fire. Three suspects are reportedly in custody, and authorities are looking for one additional suspect.\n\nOsceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. said that the last time a Kissimmee police officer was killed on duty was in 1983. \"It's just awful. We're praying for the families of these officers and for the whole KPD family,\" he said.\n\nTwo officers were also reportedly shot 150 miles north of Kissimmee in Jacksonville, Florida. One was shot in the stomach and was in critical condition, while the other was shot in the hands and was in stable condition early Saturday morning. The officers were responding to a suicide call, according to Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno. They apparently arrived to find a man with a rifle, and three people barricaded in a room, The Florida Times-Union reported. More information, like whether the incidents were connected, was not immediately available\n\n\"This is a tough time in law enforcement. I would ask that you pray for the men and women of law enforcement,\" Chief O'Dell said. President Trump answered that call, tweeting his condolences in the late night hours, writing, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. Sam Howard died Saturday from his injuries.\n\nHis colleague, Officer Matthew Baxter, died Friday night after the attack in a neighborhood of Kissimmee, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nKissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Saturday that Everett Miller was arrested several hours after the shootings late Friday.\n\nMiller already faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter and will face other charges for Howard's death, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. State police say the troopers, both taken to hospitals after the Friday night shooting in Fairchance, were in stable condition.\n\nOne officer was killed and another gravely injured late Friday night in Kissimmee in central Florida just south of the theme park hub of Orlando. Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference Saturday that a suspect, Everett Miller, was arrested several hours after the shootings.\n\nHe faces a first-degree murder charge. Authorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nThe other two officers were injured a couple of hours later in Jacksonville, one of them shot in both hands and the other in the stomach. The shooter in Jacksonville was shot and killed when police returned fire.\n\nIn Kissimmee, officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspects in an area of the city for drug activity when they were shot, O'Dell said earlier. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter died later in a hospital and Howard was in serious condition, O'Dell said.\n\nO'Dell said Baxter was a three-year veteran and Howard is a 10-year veteran, CBS affiliate WKMG-TV reports. Both men are husbands and fathers.\n\n\"Right now, as you can imagine, (the families) are completely heartbroken and devastated,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. The officers were responding to an attempted suicide call, JSO Director Mike Bruno told CBS affiliate WJAX-TV.\n\nA team of officers heard gunshots inside and feared \"an active shooter situation\" so they approached the house, Bruno said. The suspect then came out firing a high-powered rifle. He was shot and killed, and two of the police officers were wounded in the exchange of fire. On Saturday morning, Police Chief Jeff O'Dell held a news briefing at the department to give updates on the Kissimmee police shooting.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter, a veteran of three years, was killed in the shooting. Sgt. Sam Howard is reportedly in \"grave critical condition\" at the Osceola Regional Medical Center. According to the New York Daily News, O'Dell said at the press briefing on Saturday that Howard is not expected to survive.\n\nNews reports describe the incident on Friday evening as an \"ambush.\" O'Dell said the officers were unable to return fire, adding, \"they were surprised.\" He announced on Friday that three suspects were in custody, with a fourth being sought.\n\nOn Saturday morning, O'Dell said that one suspect, Everett Miller, who was arrested several hours after the shooting, faces a first-degree murder charge. He added that Miller will be transported to the Osceola County Jail in Officer Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted on Friday night that he was \"heartbroken\" about the Kissimmee officers being shot. \"Praying for a quick recovery for officer in critical condition,\" Scott added. President Trump also tweeted about the Kissimmee shooting on early Saturday morning: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\"\n\nOrange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs also tweeted about the shooting on Friday night. \"Please join in prayers for families, friends, and law enforcement,\" she added.\n\nThe Kissimmee shooting wasn't the only one in Florida on Friday night. According to the Associated Press, two officers were shot and wounded after responding to an attempted suicide at a Jacksonville home. Three other people were reportedly in the house during the incident. One police officer was shot in the stomach, and the other in both hands.\n\nKissimmee police said that Baxter was the first officer to die in the line of duty in 25 years. He is survived by a spouse -- whom local reports say is also a police officer -- and three children.\n\nSgt. Howard, a 10-year veteran on the force, remains in critical condition. {"id": "10103126", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712023143", "source": {"id": "11193", "title": "Dothan Eagle", "uri": "dothaneagle.com"}, "url": "http://www.dothaneagle.com/news/ap/national/suspect-arrested-in-killings-of-fla-officers/article_c08987fc-2999-5a44-8899-8b72873db6d7.html", "body": "CORRECTS STATUS OF SECOND POLICE OFFICER - After placing flowers at a makeshift memorial, Miguel Velez, say's a prayer for the officer that was killed on Saturday, Aug. 19, 2017 in Kissimmee, Fla. The Kissimmee Police Department says Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday from his injuries. His colleague, Officer Matthew Baxter, died Friday night after the attack in a neighborhood of Kissimmee, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando. (Red Huber/Orlando Sentinel via AP)\n\nKISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of two police officers in Florida was arrested in a bar several hours after the attack, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter, who died Friday night after the attack. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for that.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" Mr. O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition. Both had families, Mr. O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. {"id": "10104251", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712027111", "source": {"id": "88", "title": "LehighValleyLive", "uri": "lehighvalleylive.com"}, "url": "http://www.lehighvalleylive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/08/2nd_kissimmee_officer_dies_sus.html", "body": "A second Kissimmee, Florida, police officer has died and the suspect in the fatal shootings was arrested in a bar several hours after the attack, authorities said on Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter, who died Friday night after the attack. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges Miller could in connection with that killing.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller.\n\nHoward, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\n2 PA State Police troopers shot in deadly night for law enforcement\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide of a man at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger.\n\nOne of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. {"id": "10105819", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712031366", "source": {"id": "5619", "title": "Medicine Hat News", "uri": "medicinehatnews.com"}, "url": "http://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2017/08/19/suspect-in-killings-of-2-fla-officers-arrested-at-bar/", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. - A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighbourhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighbouring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. {"id": "10113975", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712057905", "source": {"id": "9517", "title": "LifeZette", "uri": "lifezette.com"}, "url": "http://www.lifezette.com/polizette/trump-tells-kissimmee-police-lethal-ambush/", "body": "One officer killed and one wounded responding to call in possible ambush in Florida\n\nPresident Donald Trump offered his solidarity and pledged his support early Saturday morning to the Kissimmee Police Department in Florida after one officer was killed and another was gravely wounded in a shooting Friday night.\n\nOfficers Matthew Baxter and Sam Howard responded to a call and were monitoring three suspects for drug activity when a fourth opened fire on the officers, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said during a press conference. Both officers were shot before they could return fire in what may have been an orchestrated ambush. Baxter died after being taken to a hospital and Howard remains in critical condition.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump tweeted early Saturday morning.\n\nBaxter served for three years with the Kissimmee department and Howard served 10 years. Both men were husbands and fathers, and Baxter's wife is also a Kissimmee officer.\n\n\"Right now, as you can imagine, [the families] are completely heartbroken and devastated,\" O'Dell said.\n\nKissimmee Mayor Jose Alvarez said in a statement that \"the entire city of Kissimmee is in mourning. We pray for all law enforcement who are out there, protecting our community.\"\n\nWhen reporters asked O'Dell if Baxter and Howard were ambushed Friday night, the police chief replied, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\n\"This is a tough time in law enforcement,\" O'Dell said. \"I would ask that you pray for the men and women of law enforcement.\"\n\nUnconnected shootings also took place in two other U.S. cities on Friday in addition to the Kissimmee tragedy. When police responded to reports of an \"active shooter situation\" where an attempted suicide took place in a house in Jacksonville, Florida, the suspect opened fire through the doorway and critically injured two officers, according to Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno. The suspect was shot and killed during the exchange.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott (R) tweeted late Friday, \"Our law enforcement officers are true heroes and we will miss these brave Floridians.\"\n\nAfter learning of the Jacksonville shooting, Scott issued a second tweet, saying, \"Just learned of two [Jacksonville officers] in danger tonight - we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nThe third shooting took place in Fairchance, Pennsylvania, at a Shop 'n Save store and left two officers injured, according to Pennsylvania State Police Trooper Melinda Bondarenka. The suspect died following the exchange of gunfire and both officers are expected to survive their injuries.\n\n\"We are deeply saddened by the shootings that occurred in our community and our thoughts and prayers go out to the victims and their families,\" Mark Burnworth Jr., Fairchance Shop 'n Save Assistant Store Manager, said in a statement, according to CBS Pittsburgh. \"We will continue to support the police department in their ongoing investigation. Providing a safe environment for our employees and guests is our number one concern.\"\n\n(photo credit, homepage and article images: Oxyman, Wikipedia)", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T13:50:00Z", Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nHoward was critically wounded and then died at the hospital on Saturday afternoon.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. (Source: AP ) Orlando shooting: At least five killed, police rule out terror angleOrlando gunman Omar Mateen was a regular at the Pulse gay club: ReportDay before Orlando shooting, Omar Mateen was calm, father says\n\nOne police officer was shot and killed and another gravely injured by gunfire while checking suspicious people in the central Florida city of Kissimmee, police said today.\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nElsewhere in Florida, two police officers were shot and injured when responding to shots fired in Jacksonville.\n\nKissimmee police officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspicious people in an area of the city known for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. Three of the suspects were arrested, and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search shooter in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen {"id": "10104950", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712029253", "source": {"id": "19270", "title": "WBOC TV 16", "uri": "wboc.com"}, "url": "http://www.wboc.com/story/36171941/suspect-in-killings-of-2-fla-officers-arrested-at-bar", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) - A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday afternoon.\n\n[Previous story, published at 10:25 p.m. ET]\n\nA 46-year-old man has been charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death of a police officer in the central Florida city of Kissimmee, Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Saturday.\n\nPolice charged Everett Glenn Miller in the killing of Kissimmee Officer Matthew Baxter. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. Three of the suspects were arrested, and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search continued in Kissimmee, a city just south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, two police officers were shot and wounded while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is
