{"id": "10109274", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 449, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712044421", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/florida-authorities-2-kissimmee-officers-shot-033442678.html", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nIn a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nU.S. Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nA spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an Sam Howard was also shot and is in grave condition, police said.\n\nThe shooting may have been an ambush, O'Dell said, as the officers responded to a suspicious activity call just before 9:30 pm Friday. {"id": "10107993", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 449, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712038918", "source": {"id": "10205", "title": "3TV, azfamily.com", "uri": "azfamily.com"}, "url": "http://www.azfamily.com/story/36171941/suspect-in-killings-of-2-fla-officers-arrested-at-bar", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) - A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nIn a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nU.S. Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nA spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an email inquiry seeking comment.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for that.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. {"id": "10022895", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711802254", "source": {"id": "793", "title": "SBS", "uri": "sbs.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/19/one-policeman-killed-florida", "body": "One police officer has been killed and another three seriously wounded in two separate shootings in central and northern Florida.\n\nOne police officer has been shot and killed and another gravely injured by gunfire while checking suspicious people in the central Florida city of Kissimmee, police said.\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nElsewhere in Florida, two police officers were shot and injured when responding to shots fired in Jacksonville.\n\nKissimmee police officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspicious people in an area of the city known for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. Three of the suspects were arrested, and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search continued in Kissimmee, a city just south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, two police officers were shot and wounded while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the {"id": "10102097", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712018985", "source": {"id": "191", "title": "WMC Action News 5", "uri": "wmcactionnews5.com"}, "url": "http://www.wmcactionnews5.com/story/36171941/suspect-arrested-in-killings-of-2-fla-officers", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) - A suspect in the fatal shooting of two police officers in Florida was arrested in a bar several hours after the attack, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter, who died Friday night after the attack. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon, and authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for that.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was heartbroken by the news of Baxter's death and was praying for a quick recovery for Howard.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"id": "10088827", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711982719", "source": {"id": "472", "title": "WOODTV.com", "uri": "woodtv.com"}, "url": "http://woodtv.com/2017/08/19/suspect-arrested-in-killing-wounding-of-fla-officers/", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of his child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Police arrested a Marine veteran in the Kissimmee shooting and charged him Saturday.\n\nThe second officer shot in Kissimmee is unlikely to survive his wounds, the city's police chief said Saturday morning.\n\nThe deadly night for Florida police officers was also marked by the shooting of two Pennsylvania state troopers, who were struck by bullets outside a store in Fairchance, Pa. south of Pittsburgh, news reports said.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter and Sgt. Richard Howard of the Kissimmee Police had been \"checking out\" a trio of people during a regular patrol in one of the city's neighborhoods when Baxter began to scuffle with one around 9:30 p.m., Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters Saturday morning. Howard, who arrived as a backup, became involved in the fight when gunshots were fired and struck both officers.\n\nNeither had time to return fire, O'Dell said. Baxter was killed. Howard was gravely wounded.\n\nAbout an hour and a half later and 160 miles north, two Jacksonville police officers were shot while responding to a call reporting a suicidal person on the city's westside. When the suspect, later identified as Derrick Rashard Brabham, exited the house with a semi-automatic rifle, he traded gunfire with the police, the Jacksonville Times-Union reported. One officer was shot in the stomach, and another was shot in both hands.\n\nBrabham was declared dead after being taken to a nearby hospital. The officers, later identified as Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell, were both in stable condition Saturday morning, according to the Times-Union.\n\nAbout two hours after the shooting in Kissimmee, police arrested 45-year-old Everett Glenn Miller when he fled to a bar around 11:30 p.m. Miller, a Marine veteran who had been recently taken into custody by the Osecola County Sheriff's Office over mental health concerns, was found with two guns, a 9mm and .22 revolver, the Orlando Sentinel reported.\n\nMiller was charged Saturday morning with resisting arrest and carrying a concealed weapon, according to Osecola County Jail records. An early investigation found that Miller had also threatened police officers online, O'Dell said. He added that his officers intended to use Baxter's handcuffs on Miller when he is taken to the county jail, and that he expects Miller will also face a murder charge, according to the Sentinel.\n\nHoward remained in critical condition in the hospital Saturday, O'Dell said, with \"not much hope that he will survive this.\"\n\nBaxter, 27, had served in the Kissimmee Police Department for three years and was married to a fellow officer; Howard had been an officer in the city for 10. Both were wearing body armor but no body cameras when they were struck.\n\n\"They are both wonderful men, family men. They are both very committed to the community,\" O'Dell said, according to the Sentinel. \"They were the epitome of what you ask for in law enforcement officers.\"", "dateTime": Asked whether they were ambushed, he said: \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nMr Baxter, who had been with the department three years, died later in hospital.\n\nMr Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in a serious condition, Mr O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers, both of whom had families, were checking three suspects when a fourth opened fire.\n\nThree of the suspects were arrested and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search continued in Kissimmee, a city just south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, two police officers were shot and wounded while responding to reports of a gunman in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott sent tweets about the four officers, saying: \"We stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida\".\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" Mr O'Dell said of the two incidents. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. {"id": "10125378", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 449, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712094290", "source": {"id": "6602", "title": "WTOP", "uri": "wtop.com"}, "url": "http://wtop.com/national/2017/08/florida-authorities-say-2-kissimmee-officers-shot/", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nIn a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nU.S. Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nGov. Rick Scott on Saturday evening issued an executive order removing the case from Ayala and reassigning it.\n\n\"Today, I am using my executive authority to reassign this case to State Attorney Brad King to ensure the victims of last night's attack and their families receive the justice they deserve,\" Scott said in the order.\n\nA spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an email inquiry seeking comment.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Sam Howard were responding to a suspicious activity call.\n\nAccording to O'Dell, the casualties may have occurred during an ambush when the officers were responding to the call.\n\nThe police chief said that within minutes after the officers reached the spot, gunfire erupted, surprising the officers, who were not able to return fire.\n\nO'Dell added, \"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the road way.\"\n\nThe police chief said that Baxter, a three-year-veteran of the Kissimmee Police Department, was pronounced dead at the scene, while Howard remains hospitalized.\n\nHe added, \"Nobody was being placed in handcuffs. If all things checked out, the officers would have been on their way.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the police also noted that three people had been arrested after the shooting and a manhunt had been launched for the fourth person.\n\nO'Dell said, \"At this time, we have a strong suspect in custody that we are interviewing.\"\n\nAuthorities also added that in a separate incident, two other officers were hurt in gunfire the same night.\n\nOn Friday night, two officers in Jacksonville, Florida, were also injured.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said that when officers arrived to attend an attempted suicide call, they encountered a man armed with a high-powered rifle and exchanged gunfire.\n\none officer was struck in both of his hands while the other was hit in his stomach during the shooting, Bruno said.\n\nHe added that the suspect, who was also injured, died after he was taken to a local hospital.\n\nMeanwhile, Melinda Bondarenka, a spokeswoman for the Pennsylvania State Police said that two state troopers were shot in Pennsylvania late on Friday night and that their condition remains unknown.\n\nFlorida Gov. {"id": "10082214", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 337, "label": "dmoz/Business/Consumer Goods and Services/Office Products", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Consumer_Goods_and_Services/Office_Products", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711963702", "source": {"id": "104", "title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2017/08/19/1-police-officer-killed-three-injured-in-2-separate-florida-shootings/", "body": "Two officers stand guard outside Osceola Regional Medical Center after two Kissimmee police officers were shot Friday night. Police said one officer was killed and another gravely injured in the central Florida city. (Stephen M. Dowell/Orlando Sentinel/AP)\n\nOne officer was killed and three others were injured in two separate Florida shootings Friday night, outbreaks of violence against police that reverberated across the nation.\n\nThe first shooting incident left one officer dead and another \"gravely\" injured in Kissimmee, Fla., just south of Orlando. Officers were responding to a report of suspicious activity in a high-crime area when they were taken by surprise, officials said.\n\nThe second shooting, about 90 minutes later in Jacksonville, left two officers injured. Police were dispatched to deal with an armed suicidal man when he came out firing.\n\nAll the shootings were \"deflating to law enforcement and heartbreaking,\" Kissimmee Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters, shortly after he announced that Officer Matthew Baxter had died of his injuries.\n\nAbout 9:30 p.m. Friday, Baxter and Sgt. Sam Howard were on patrol in a neighborhood in the north part of the city where police were trying to crack down on heightened drug activity. The officers were searching several suspects when they got into a scuffle with one, who opened fire, O'Dell said at the news conference.\n\nThe officers didn't have time to return fire, O'Dell said. \"It looked like they were surprised by the gunfire.\"\n\nHoward remained in grave condition at a hospital near the shooting, O'Dell said, and there was \"not much hope that he will survive this.\"\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter succumbed to his injuries. Officer Sam Howard is in very grave condition. pic.twitter.com/oXypORJaIn\n\n-- Kissimmee Police (@kissimmeepolice) August 19, 2017\n\nPolice began searching for the shooter and announced Saturday morning that they'd arrested Everett Miller, who is charged with murder.\n\nAs investigators learned more about Miller, O'Dell said he was disheartened to learn that the suspect had posted violent anti-police comments on social media and that no one had reported it to authorities. O'Dell didn't detail the comments.\n\nNearly two hours later and 165 miles north, police officers in Jacksonville were summoned to a home on the city's west side to defuse a situation involving a suicidal man armed with a gun, according to the Florida Times-Union. There was an extra element of danger: Dispatchers told the officers three other people were inside the home with the armed man.\n\n[U.S. police chiefs blast Trump for endorsing 'police brutality']\n\nAs a team of officers approached the house, they heard gunshots and feared they were dealing with an active shooter.\n\nThe suspect came out firing a high-powered rifle, police said. He was killed during the ensuing firefight with officers and had not been identified early Saturday.\n\nTwo officers were wounded, though their injuries are not life-threatening. The three other people in the house were okay.\n\nAnd around 8 p.m. Friday, two Pennsylvania State troopers were shot southeast of Pittsburgh after stopping a man who had an outstanding warrant, according to Pittsburgh ABC-affiliate WPVI. One trooper managed to return fire, killing the suspect.\n\nAs the police agencies sorted through the aftermath of the attacks, President Trump tweeted a show of solidarity.\n\nMy thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!#LESM\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 19, 2017\n\nAnd Florida Gov. Rick Scott (R) said he was praying for the Kissimmee Police Department, which had lost a \"brave officer.\"\n\nUPDATE: Heartbroken to hear loss of @kissimmeepolice officer Matthew Baxter. Another officer shot him.\n\nPolice say they shot two dogs who 'charged' at an officer. {"id": "10125377", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 449, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712094288", "source": {"id": "104", "title": "Washington Post", "uri": "washingtonpost.com"}, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/suspect-in-killings-of-2-fla-officers-arrested-at-bar/2017/08/19/df8a61a8-8540-11e7-9e7a-20fa8d7a0db6_story.html", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. -- A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nIn a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nU.S. Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nGov. Rick Scott on Saturday evening issued an executive order removing the case from Ayala and reassigning it.\n\n\"Today, I am using my executive authority to reassign this case to State Attorney Brad King to ensure the victims of last night's attack and their families receive the justice they deserve,\" Scott said in the order.\n\nA spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an email inquiry seeking comment.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"id": "10125381", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712094297", "source": {"id": "10700", "title": "WFTV", "uri": "wftv.com"}, "url": "http://www.wftv.com/news/local/police-2-kissimmee-police-officers-fatally-shot/595071270", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. - Two Kissimmee police officers are dead after they were shot Friday evening while checking out a report of a suspicious person, Kissimmee police Chief Jeff O'Dell said.\n\nKissimmee police Officer Matthew Baxter and Sgt. Sam Howard were shot in a scuffle at about 9:30 p.m. at Palmway and East Cypress streets near East Irlo Bronson Memorial Highway and North Main Street, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter died of his injuries at the scene. Howard succumbed to his injuries at Osceola Regional Medical Center Saturday.\n\n\"I am so proud of the sworn and civilian members of our department by acting quickly to identify the suspect and bring him to justice,\" said O'Dell in a statement. \"We will mourn over the next few day; we will get through this and we love them for what they do.\"\n\nRead: Man charged with first-degree murder in Kissimmee officers shooting deaths\n\nRead: Timeline of shootings of Kissimmee police officers\n\nThe officers were being proactive when they interacted with three people and didn't handcuff them, O'Dell said.\n\nAn Osceola County deputy arrested the suspected gunman, Everett Glenn Miller, 45, at about 11:30 p.m. Friday at Roscoe's Bar & Package at North Main and Tremont streets, O'Dell said.\n\nThe deputy tackled Miller, who had a 9 mm pistol and .22-caliber revolver on him, O'Dell said. Miller was charged with one count of first-degree murder.\n\nDetails of the exact exchange between Baxter, Howard and Miller are still under investigation, KPD said.\n\nWatch: Police escort for fallen Kissimmee officer Matthew Baxter\n\nWatch the Kissimmee police chief's news conference below:\n\nRead: Trump, community reacts to shootings of Kissimmee police officers\n\nPolice said two other people were being questioned, but no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nA procession of police vehicles escorted Baxter's body to the Orange County Medical Examiner's Office in Orlando shortly after 2 a.m. Saturday.\n\nBaxter, who was hired by the agency three years ago, was married to another Kissimmee police officer. The couple has four small children.\n\nRead: 2 Jacksonville officers shot while responding to suicide call; suspect dead\n\nHoward, who was raised in the area, was hired by the agency 10 years ago, O'Dell said. Channel 9 learned that he had a daughter and that his wife is a teacher at Central Avenue Elementary School, which is two blocks away from where the shooting occurred.\n\n\"This is a tough time in law enforcement,\" O'Dell said. \"I would ask that you pray for the men and women of law enforcement.\"\n\nThe principal of Central Avenue Elementary School, Sharon Hahn, said the school is working out plans to help faculty and students cope with the tragedy.\n\n\"One of the things we talked about this morning is just making sure that when the kids come back on Monday that we talk to the kids about what happened,\" she said. \"And that we talk to the kids about how we need love and peace in the world.\"\n\nO'Dell said officers and residents will continue to mourn in the coming days, but he said, \"We will get through this.\"\n\nHe said that the shootings aren't a reflection of the community.\n\nSuspect will be transported to the Osceola County Jail in Officer Baxter's handcuffs ~Chief O'Dell -- Kissimmee Police (@kissimmeepolice)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\n\"I'm so proud of the sworn and civilian members of our department for bringing the suspect to justice,\" O'Dell said. \"We've got to come together as a nation and get our community involved.\"\n\nThe City of Kissimmee has set up a bank account through SunTrust for those who would like to donate to the fallen officers' families. Donations can be made at any SunTrust Bank beginning Monday, officials said.\n\nWatch: Details on the 2 offers shot in the line of duty\n\nBaxter was the first Kissimmee police officer to die in the line of duty more than two decades. Kissimmee police Sgt. Douglas Odell Parsons died in 1993 of a heart attack after a department physical fitness test.\n\nQuiet at the Kissimmee Police Department. We found a single candle and a marble notebook. {"id": "10123594", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 449, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712088566", "source": {"id": "566", "title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/6b85546689744819aa7a64cd3ca6cee6/Article_2017-08-19-US--Officers%20Shot-Florida/id-439318ea30e44432bd1bc38e5afdc892", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A police officer in Florida died from his injuries Saturday, a day after his colleague was killed when a suspect fired at them during a scuffle while they were on patrol. The suspect was later arrested at a bar.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard died Saturday afternoon at a hospital where he had been taken following Friday night's attack in Kissimmee, Florida, located south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter died Friday night, a short time after authorities say he was shot by 45-year-old Everett Miller.\n\nMiller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Baxter. Authorities hadn't yet said what charges he could face for Howard's death.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThey found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller was taken to jail wearing Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, two other officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where the mother of the man's child, their 19-month-old toddler, the woman's mother and a family friend were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed Derrick Brabham, who was killed by the officers.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nIn a suburb of Birmingham, Alabama, a suspect was fatally shot and an officer injured after they got into a struggle.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was \"heartbroken\" by the attacks on the officers.\n\nU.S. Rep. Darren Soto said Saturday that he will ask for American flags to be flown over the U.S. Capitol and he plans to ask for a moment of silence on the floor of the U.S. House to honor the officers.\n\nThe officers were fatally shot in a district where the top prosecutor says she will no longer seek the death penalty. State Attorney Aramis Ayala announced earlier this year that she wouldn't seek the death penalty, explaining it's not a deterrent and it drags on for years for the victims' relatives. The announcement came as her office was building a case against Markeith Loyd, who is charged with the fatal shooting of an Orlando Police lieutenant.\n\nGov. Rick Scott on Saturday evening issued an executive order removing the case from Ayala and reassigning it.\n\n\"Today, I am using my executive authority to reassign this case to State Attorney Brad King to ensure the victims of last night's attack and their families receive the justice they deserve,\" Scott said in the order.\n\nA spokeswoman for Ayala didn't respond to an email inquiry seeking (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday.\n\nKissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the abdomen.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Baxter, who was married to another officer, has three young children.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nMayor Jose Alvarez said in a statement: \"Our thoughts and prayers go out to the family of our fallen officer, Matthew Baxter who lost his life in the line of duty. Our prayers also go out to Sergeant Sam Howard and his family as he remains in critical condition.\n\n\"The entire city of Kissimmee is in mourning. We pray for all law enforcement who are out there, protecting our community.\"\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted that his \"thoughts and prayers\" were with the local police \"and their loved ones.\"\n\nIn Jacksonville, police officers were responding to a call about an attempted suicide at a house. Gunfire was heard from outside the property as officers arrived, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director of Patrol and Enforcement Mike Bruno told NBC News.\n\nBefore officers even entered the house, the suspect began shooting at them through the doorway and there was an exchange of gunfire in which two officers were struck, one of them in the stomach, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect is dead and it's not yet known if body cameras were worn or activated.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two troopers were shot and a suspect killed after an incident near a store on West Church Street, Fairchance, Fayette County, Pennsylvania State Police Trooper Melinda Bondarenka said in a statement.\n\nOne of the troopers was flown from the scene to a hospital in Morgantown, West Virginia and the other was taken to a Sam Howard, a 10-year veteran, was critically injured and the prognosis for him \"does not look good,\" said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Friday night. We are with you! #LESM,\" he wrote. (LESM seems to stand for \"Law Enforcement Social Media.\")\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted that he was heartbroken Friday night. \"Our law enforcement officers are true heroes and we will miss these brave Floridians,\" he said. \"Tonight we lost a brave officer - Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero. Praying for @kissimmeepolice,\" he added.\n\nChief O'Dell echoed those sentiments, saying during a media briefing, \"This is a tough time in law enforcement. Sam Howard were responding to a suspicious activity call just before 9:30 pm Friday in Kissimmee. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighbourhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighbouring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. {"id": "10128534", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712103545", "source": {"id": "8487", "title": "TBO.com", "uri": "tbo.com"}, "url": "http://tampabay.com/news/two-kissimmee-police-officers-shot-to-death/2334399", "body": "KISSIMMEE -- A Marine veteran who once worked for U.S. Special Operations Command at MacDill Air Force Base has been charged with first-degree murder in the deaths of two Kissimmee police officers.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter, a three-year veteran, died Friday night, and a second officer, Sgt. Sam Howard, died Saturday, Kissimmee police Chief Jeff O'Dell said.\n\nEverett Glenn Miller, 45, was arrested Friday.\n\nMiller once served as the senior enlisted adviser to the U.S. Special Operations Command Joint Intelligence Center at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, according to spokesman Ken McGraw.\n\nMcGraw said he was told Miller retired from SOCom in 2010, but his service records were not immediately available.\n\nMiller was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation show that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, the Kissimmee police chief said.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They wore body armor under their uniforms but they weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nDeputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him. He was also charged with resisting arrest and carrying a concealed handgun.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing a fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they thought there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, had served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife had one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"I am so proud of the sworn and civilian members of our department by acting quickly to identify the suspect and bring him to justice,\" O'Dell said. \"We will mourn over the next few days . . . we will get through this and we love them for what they do.\"\n\nPresident Donald J. Trump tweeted Friday night: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @kissimmeepolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\"\n\nGov. Rick Scott tweeted he was heartbroken by the news. \"Tonight we lost a brave officer -- Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero. Praying for @kissimmeepolice,\" Scott wrote.\n\nIn a separate event in Jacksonville overnight Friday, two Jacksonville police offers were shot responding to an attempted suicide, authorities said.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff Mike Williams said Saturday that officers Michael Fox and Kevin Jarrell are in stable condition following Friday night's confrontation with an armed man who was killed by the officers.\n\nWilliams said at a news conference that the suspect, Derrick Brabham, was making threats inside a home with his girlfriend, their 19-month-old baby and another woman. None of them were injured.\n\nAfter officers arrived at the home, they heard gunfire from inside and decided to enter the house.\n\nThe sheriff says Brabham opened fire with a semiautomatic rifle as they entered the house.\n\nResidents flocked to Kissimmee police headquarters Saturday, bringing food and shaking the hands of officers to express their condolences. At 5:35 p.m., they had a moment of silence near a memorial for fallen officers outside.\n\nO'Dell said the news is especially difficult for members of his agency, as they must press forward while suffering the loss of two co-workers and friends.\n\n\"We do not get to stop and cry for someone we've lost or mourn our hero,\" O'Dell said. \"At the time we go through it, the men and women of law enforcement are required to continue working and bring this individual to justice.\"\n\nA prayer vigil will be held at the Hope Mission Church, 1431 Palmway St., at 3 p.m. today. The church sits at the intersection where Howard and Baxter were shot.\n\nThe city of Kissimmee has set up an account with SunTrust Bank for the Howard and Baxter's families. Donors can go to any SunTrust Bank location beginning Monday to contribute, a city spokeswoman said.\n\nThe Kissimmee Police department has more than 100 officers. O'Dell took over the department in August 2016.\n\nInformation from the Orlando Sentinel was used in this report.", "dateTime": "2017-08-20T02:47:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 4556, (AP) -- One police officer was shot and killed and another gravely injured by gunfire while checking suspicious people in the central Florida city of Kissimmee, police said early Saturday.\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nElsewhere in Florida, two police officers were shot and injured when responding to shots fired in Jacksonville.\n\nKissimmee police officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspicious people in an area of the city known for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. Three of the suspects were arrested, and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search continued in Kissimmee, a city just south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, two police officers were shot and wounded while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. {"id": "10073108", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711940191", "source": {"id": "2989", "title": "The Detroit News", "uri": "detroitnews.com"}, "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/nation/2017/08/19/florida-officers-shooting-suspect/104749578/", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nKissimmee, Fla. -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was heartbroken by the news of Baxter's death and was praying for a quick recovery for Howard.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"id": "10112809", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 374, "label": "dmoz/Society/Military/Veterans", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Military/Veterans", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712054843", "source": {"id": "971", "title": "Los Angeles Times", "uri": "latimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-florida-20170819-story.html", "body": "Two Kissimmee police officers have died after being shot during a routine traffic stop Friday night, authorities said.\n\nSgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard and Officer Matthew Baxter were shot in the McLaren Circle area of Kissimmee, according to a department spokeswoman.\n\nHoward died off his wounds Saturday. Baxter died Friday night, shortly after the shooting.\n\nTwo Jacksonville, Fla., police officers were also shot on Friday night, according to the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. Both survived.\n\nTwo Pennsylvania state troopers were also reported shot late Friday.\n\nBaxter was investigating three suspicious people about 9:30 p.m., when Howard came to help and a \"scuffle\" broke out, Kissimmee police Chief Jeff O'Dell said. That's when Marine veteran Everett Glenn Miller, 45, allegedly shot the officers.\n\nInvestigators are still working to understand the details of what happened in the moments before the shooting, officials said.\n\nThe officers -- who were wearing body armor under their uniforms -- apparently did not have a chance to return fire. O'Dell said \"it looked like they were surprised\" by the gunfire.\n\nMiller fled to a local bar, where Osceola County sheriff's deputies found him about 11:30 p.m. When they approached him, Miller reached for his waistband -- but a fast-acting deputy tackled him and he was arrested, O'Dell said. Miller was carrying a 9-millimeter pistol and a .22-caliber revolver, the police chief said.\n\nThe Sheriff's Office recently took Miller into custody under Florida's Baker Act, which allows involuntary commitment of people in mental health crises. Miller, who has no criminal record in Florida, was enlisted in the Marines from 1989 to 2010, according to military records.\n\nO'Dell said the community needs to help law enforcement. Social media posts showed Miller threatening law enforcement, O'Dell said, \"but we never got a call on that.''\n\nA Facebook page believed to be Miller's is filled with posts expressing anger over racism, slavery and the Ku Klux Klan. In one post, he shared a meme encouraging people to \"shoot back\" with a photo of Martin Luther King Jr.\n\n\"You can poke a tie up dog for so long,\" Miller wrote.\n\nO'Dell said his officers would press forward with their duties while mourning their co-workers and friends.\n\n\"We do not get to stop and cry for someone we've lost or mourn our hero,\" O'Dell said. \"At the time we go through it, the men and women of law enforcement are required to continue working and bring this individual to justice.\"\n\nBaxter, 27, was married to a fellow Kissimmee police officer and had four young children, O'Dell said. Howard, 36, had one child.\n\n\"They are both wonderful men, family men. They are both very committed to the community,\" O'Dell said. \"They were the epitome of what you ask for in law enforcement officers.\"\n\nThe last Kissimmee officer killed on the job was shot in 1983.\n\nPresident Trump and Vice President Mike Pence said on social media that their \"thoughts and prayers\" were with the Kissimmee police.\n\nIt has also been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in a Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest a man suspected of killing his ex-girlfriend.\n\nOrange Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Baxter, who was married to another officer, has three young children.\n\nThe officers were checking three of the suspects when a fourth opened fire. One of the original three suspects fled and was being sought, and the other three were arrested. Broadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed a housing complex as the search continued early Saturday morning.\n\nMayor Jose Alvarez said in a statement: \"Our thoughts and prayers go out to the family of our fallen officer, Matthew Baxter who lost his life in the line of duty. the suspect began shooting at them through the doorway and there was an exchange of gunfire in which two officers were struck, one of them in the stomach, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect is dead and it's not yet known if body cameras were worn or activated.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two troopers were shot and a suspect killed after an incident near a store on West Church Street, Fairchance, Fayette County,
