{"id": "10105734", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712030826", "source": {"id": "971", "title": "Los Angeles Times", "uri": "latimes.com"}, "url": "http://www.latimes.com/nation/os-kissimmee-police-shooting-folo-20170819-story.html", "body": "A second Kissimmee Police officer has died after a Friday night attack on law enforcement.\n\nSgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday from gunshot wounds he suffered when he and fellow officer Matthew Baxter were shot during a routine stop in the McLaren Circle area, according to department spokeswoman.\n\nBaxter died Friday night shortly after the shooting.\n\nBaxter was investigating three suspicious people about 9:30 p.m. near Palmway and Cypress streets when Howard came to help and a \"scuffle\" broke out, O'Dell said. That's when police say Marine veteran Everett Glenn Miller, 45, shot the officers.\n\nInvestigators are still working to understand the details of what happened in the moments before the shooting, officials said.\n\nThe officers -- who were wearing body armor underneath their uniforms -- did not have a chance to return fire. O'Dell said \"it looked like they were surprised\" by the gunfire.\n\nMiller fled to Roscoe's Bar at 2344 N. Orange Blossom Trail, where Osceola County Sheriff's Office detectives found him about 11:30 p.m. When the officers approached him, Miller reached for his waistband -- but a fast-acting deputy tackled him to the ground and arrested him, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Extremely brave and heroic actions by the deputy, there were other people in the vicinity,\" O'Dell said. \"They went hands-on, tackled him to the ground and secured him [and] located a 9mm and .22 revolver on his person.\"\n\nWhen officers took Miller to the Osceola County Jail Saturday, they placed Baxter's handcuffs on his wrists, O'Dell said.\n\nThe Sheriff's Office recently took Miller into custody under Florida's Baker Act, which allows involuntary commitment of people in mental health crises. Miller, who has no criminal record in Florida, was enlisted in the Marines from 1989 to 2010, according to military records.\n\nO'Dell said the community needs to work with law enforcement. Social media posts showed Miller threatening law enforcement, O'Dell said, \"but we never got a call on that.''\n\nA Facebook page believed to be Miller's is filled with posts expressing anger over racism, slavery and the KKK. In one post, he shared a meme encouraging people to \"shoot back\" with a photo of Martin Luther King Jr.\n\n\"You can poke a tie [sic] up dog for so long,\" Miller wrote.\n\nO'Dell said the news is especially difficult for members of his agency, as they must press forward while suffering the loss of a coworker and friend.\n\n\"We do not get to stop and cry for someone we've lost or mourn our hero,\" O'Dell said. \"At the time we go through it, the men and women of law enforcement are required to continue working and bring this individual to justice.\"\n\nBaxter, 27, was married to a fellow Kissimmee Police officer and had four young children, O'Dell said. Howard, 36, had one child.\n\n\"They are both wonderful men, family men. They are both very committed to the community,\" O'Dell said. \"They were the epitome of what you ask for in law enforcement officers.\"\n\nO'Dell praised other police agencies, including the Osceola and Orange sheriff's offices and Orlando Police Department, for their help.\n\n\"Everyone came to the scene without being asked,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe last Kissimmee officer killed on the job was shot in 1983.\n\nPresident Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence said on social media that their \"thoughts and prayers\" were with the Kissimmee Police.\n\nThe area where the shooting happened has historically been plagued by crime. O'Dell said Howard and Baxter were doing proactive police work there because it is known for drug sales. In 2008, law enforcement led a crackdown on drugs and violence that \"ravaged the McLaren Circle area,\" according to the U.S. Attorney's Office.\n\nOfficers arrested 19 people during that operation, and witnesses in subsequent court cases testified crime was so rampant that mobile businesses such as FedEx, UPS, pizza delivery and taxi services \"refused to enter the area to provide services to residents.\" Even the U.S. Postal Service stopped its route through the neighborhood for a time.\n\nKissimmee Police Officer Matthew Baxter was 'a good spirit' \"\n\nA prayer vigil will be held at the Hope Mission Church, 1431 Palmway St., at 3 p.m. Sunday. The church sits at the intersection where Howard and Baxter were shot.\n\nThe City of Kissimmee has set up an account with SunTrust Bank for individuals interested in donating to Howard and Baxter's families. Donors can go to any SunTrust Bank location beginning Monday to contribute, a city spokeswoman said.\n\nKissimmee Police has more than 100 officers. O'Dell took over the department in August 2016.\n\nKissimmee Police mourns death of Sgt. Sam Howard \"\n\nTwo Jacksonville police officers were also shot on the Westside of Jacksonville, according to the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. Two Pennsylvania Troopers were also reported shot late Friday.\n\nIt has also been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\ncdoornbos@orlandosentinel.com, 407-650-6931 or @CaitlinDoornbos\n\nTwo police officers shot in Kissimmee \"\n\nInteractive map: Every homicide in Central Florida \"", "dateTime": Sam Howard was in critical condition after they were shot while responding to a call at 9:30 p.m. in the Florida city Friday night, the Orlando Sentinel reported.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy,\" O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter was pronounced dead at the scene and Howard was taken to a hospital in critical condition.\n\nPolice arrested three people connected to the shooting and are searching for a fourth, CNN reported.\n\n\"At this time, we have a strong suspect in custody that we are interviewing,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said it was too early to determine if the shooting was an ambush, but added it was \"leading toward that.\"\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted condolences following news of the shooting on Friday night.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the Kissimmee Police and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTwo other officers were wounded in a separate shooting in Jacksonville on Friday while responding to an attempted suicide call.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff's Office gunfire with the suspect.\n\nThe suspect was also wounded in the shooting and died after being taken to a local hospital.\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott offered prayers for the wounded Jacksonville officers as well as the two involved in the Kissimmee shooting.\n\n\"Heartbroken to hear loss of Kissimmee Police officer Matthew Baxter,\" he wrote. \"Praying for a quick recovery for officer in {"id": "10072954", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711939636", "source": {"id": "138", "title": "The Denver Post", "uri": "denverpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/08/19/florida-police-officers-shot/", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\nO'Dell says Baxter died later in a hospital, and Howard was in serious condition.\n\nThree suspects are in custody and a fourth is being sought in connection with that crime.\n\nMeanwhile in Jacksonville, two officers are hospitalized after attempting to apprehend an active shooting suspect on the city's westside.\n\nThe shooting occurred when a contact team of four or five officers approached a home just before 11 p.m. The officers were called out to a report of an attempted suicide, police said.\n\nThe Jacksonville Sheriff's Office says when the contact team reached the home, a shooter with a high-powered rifle opened fire at the officers through the front doorway of the home.\n\nThe officers and the suspect then exchanged gunfire. Two officers and the suspect were wounded in the exchange, police said.\n\nThe suspect and the officers were transported to a local hospital, where the suspect died.\n\nOne officer is in critical condition after being shot in the stomach, while the other was shot in both hands and is in stable condition, police said.\n\nThe three victims inside the home are now safe, a police spokesperson said.\n\n\u00a9 2017 CBS Interactive Inc. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday (Aug. 19) afternoon, a day after Officer Matthew Baxter died at the scene of a shooting in the central Florida city near Orlando.\n\nEarlier Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Everett Glenn Miller, 45, had been charged with first-degree murder in Baxter's killing.\n\nThe officers approached Miller and two other men before 9:30 p.m. Friday. Within minutes, gunfire erupted, surprising the officers, who were not able to return fire, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the Kissimmee Police Department, was pronounced dead.\n\nMiller is the only one charged of three people the police questioned, the chief said. He also faces charges of carrying a concealed weapon and resisting arrest.\n\nO'Dell said he was found at a bar and had a 9 mm pistol and a .22-caliber revolver.\n\nFollowing the news of the shooting, President Donald Trump tweeted his condolences.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. {"id": "10070595", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711933500", "source": {"id": "192", "title": "WAFB", "uri": "wafb.com"}, "url": "http://www.wafb.com/story/36171941/suspect-arrested-in-killing-wounding-of-fla-officers", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) - A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott tweeted he was heartbroken by the news of Baxter's death and was praying for a quick recovery for Howard.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. (AP) - One police officer was shot and killed and another gravely injured by gunfire while checking suspicious people in the central Florida city of Kissimmee, police said early Saturday.\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nElsewhere in Florida, two police officers were shot and injured when responding to shots fired in Jacksonville.\n\nKissimmee police officers Sam Howard and Matthew Baxter were checking suspicious people in an area of the city known for drug activity when they were shot, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nBaxter, a three-year veteran of the department, died later in a hospital and Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in serious condition, O'Dell said. Both had families, he said.\n\nThe officers were checking three suspects when a fourth suspect opened fire. Three of the suspects were arrested, and officers were searching for a fourth.\n\nBroadcaster WFTV showed aerial footage of police cars with lights flashing swarmed at a housing complex as the search continued in Kissimmee, a city just south of the theme park hub of Orlando.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, two police officers were shot and wounded while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott sent Tweets about the four officers, saying \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nWhen O'Dell held his brief news conference outside the hospital where the two fallen Kissimee officers had been taken, reports already had surfaced of two more officers shot in Jacksonville to the north.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of those reports. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. {"id": "10069619", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711931288", "source": {"id": "566", "title": "Associated Press", "uri": "hosted2.ap.org"}, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/6b85546689744819aa7a64cd3ca6cee6/Article_2017-08-19-US--Officers%20Shot-Florida/id-35d6d590081c4c428d0af8c932d28a04", "body": "KISSIMMEE, Fla. (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of a sergeant was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday. Kissimmee is located south of the theme park hub of Orlando, Florida.\n\nDuring a patrol late Friday of a neighborhood with a history of drug activity, Baxter was \"checking out\" three people, including Miller, when the officer got into a scuffle with Miller. Howard, his sergeant, responded as backup, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire. They weren't wearing body cameras.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nMiller, 45, was a Marine veteran and was recently involuntarily committed for a mental evaluation by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office. The early stages of the investigation shows that Miller had made threats to law enforcement on Facebook, O'Dell said.\n\nAs of Saturday morning, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition\" at the hospital, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It's grave. Not much hope that he will survive this,\" the police chief said.\n\nBaxter, 27, had been with the Kissimmee Police Department for three years. He was married to another Kissimmee police officer and they have four children.\n\nHoward, 36, has served with the Kissimmee Police Department for 10 years. He and his wife have one child, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They are two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two committed to doing it the right way.\"\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. One of the officers was shot in both hands and the other was shot in the stomach.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nPresident Trump tweeted early Saturday that his thoughts and prayers were with the Kissimmee Police Department. \"We are with you!\" he said.\n\nFlorida Gov. They did not have an opportunity to return fire, he said.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he said, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nTwo other police officers were shot and wounded in the northern Florida city of Jacksonville while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of the Jacksonville shooting. \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nRead More:\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott issued a statement on Twitter saying he was \"hearbroken,\" adding that \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nTensions have been high between police and minority communities in recent years following a spate of high-profile killings of unarmed African American men by white police and their subsequent acquittal.\n\nNumerous protests have been held against police brutality in the United States. {"id": "10021555", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 337, "label": "dmoz/Business/Consumer Goods and Services/Office Products", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Consumer_Goods_and_Services/Office_Products", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711798836", "source": {"id": "4362", "title": "Heavy.com", "uri": "heavy.com"}, "url": "http://heavy.com/news/2017/08/kissimmee-police-officers-shot-jacksonville-florida-fairchance-pennsylvania-six/", "body": "Kissimmee Police officer Matthew Baxter (center, in uniform) was shot and killed in an \"ambush\" attack August 18.\n\nIn the span of just a few hours, six American police officers were shot in separate incidents in three different cities in Florida and Pennsylvania.\n\nTwo officers were shot in each of the three locations.\n\nOne of the officers, in Kissimmee, Florida, has died from his wounds in what the police chief says may have been an ambush. He was identified as Officer Matthew Baxter, a 3-year police veteran who is a father of three. A second officer, Sgt. Sam Howard, was now described by the police chief as being in very, very grave condition after earlier reports that both officers had died.\n\nKissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said in a news conference, \"These are beloved fathers and husbands and sons. So we are doing everything we can to support the families.\" Police shared the above photo of Officer Baxter in June with the caption, \"Officer Baxter connects with a local family. Conversations and Slurpee Coupons. All about positive interactions. #OperationChill.\"\n\nThe two officers shot in Pennsylvania are in stable condition. The officers shot in Jacksonville, Florida, are in critical and stable condition. They were shot with a high-powered rifle, according to police.\n\nThe names of the suspects and other officers were not yet released. Two of the suspects are dead.\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted on the Kissimmee police shooting.\n\nHere's a rundown of what happened in each city:\n\nThe shooting in Kissimmee, Florida left officer Baxter dead and Sgt. Howard gravely injured and occurred in the area of Cypress and Palm Street around 9:30 p.m. on Friday, August 18, according to ABC Action News. Two suspects were in custody and one was still being sought.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come to speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy, one that has resulted in the death of one of our police officers and the grave, critical situation of another,\" the police chief said in the news conference. \"This evening, Sgt. Sam Howard, a 10-year veteran of the Kissimmee police department and officer Matthew Baxter, a three-year veteran of the Kissimmee police department checked out suspicious persons...in the city.\"\n\nThe chief said the officers were surprised and didn't get a round off.\n\nA few minutes later, police received the first 911 call that the officers were shot. Responding officers found \"two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" the chief said.\n\n\"Heartbreaking loss of two of Kissimee's finest officers,\" Orange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs tweeted. \"Please join in prayers for families, friends and law enforcement.\"\n\nWrote one woman of Officer Baxter on Facebook, \"RIP Kissimmee Officer Matthew Baxter. My family knew him and we are heart broken. We are praying for the family and for all those grieving the death of our officers tonight, who serve to protect our community. May peace be with you all.\"\n\nOn Friday evening August 18, the Jacksonville, Florida Sheriff's Department tweeted, \"Two police officers shot: Westside of #Jacksonville.\" Police said in a news briefing that the officers were shot with a high-powered rifle through a door when they arrived at the scene. \"1 officer shot in both hands, 2nd officer shot in the stomach. 'They stared danger in the face,'\" journalist Meagan Harris reported of the police comments at the briefing.\n\nAccording to the JSO briefing by Mike Bruno, officers were dispatched to an attempted suicide call where there were \"three additional victims inside the house that had retreated to a back bedroom for their safety. While the officers were en route, the suspect armed himself with a high-powered rifle.\" The officers, who were in a group of four-five, could hear gunfire coming from the house. They formed a contact team. They thought it was an active shooter situation inside the house, so they approached the house, the media spokesperson for police said.\n\nAs they approached the house and attempted to enter one of the doorways, \"the suspect began shooting through the door at the officers.\" There was an exchange of gunfire. During that exchange of gunfire, two officers were struck by bullets, as was the suspect. One officer was struck in both hands, and the other officer was shot in his stomach with the rifle fire, said authorities.\n\n\"He engaged the officers before they made entry into the house,\" Bruno said of the suspect. The house is set back from the roadway quite a bit.\n\nThe three people inside the house who weren't the suspect were not injured.\n\nOne officer was later listed as being in critical condition, one was in stable condition, and the suspect was dead. \"We thought we had an active shooter type situation,\" the media spokesperson explained.\n\nYou can watch the police briefing here:\n\n\"We often talk about the inherent dangers of police work, but tonight those dangers were all too real for these police officers. As they were approaching the house, they knew they were staring danger in the face, and yet they moved forward to meet their commitment that they swore to take to this community,\" Bruno said.\n\nThe department requested prayers for the officers.\n\nAccording to CBS Local, two state troopers were shot in Fairchance, Pennsylvania at around 8 p.m. on the evening of Friday, August 18.\n\nUniontown State Police told the television station that \"a situation\" unfolded at a Shop 'n Save as the officers tried to serve a warrant. In this case, reports CBS local, the suspect is dead. One trooper was shot in the stomach and the other in the hand; one was in surgery, reported the television station.\n\nThe officers were described as being alert and in stable condition.\n\nThis Five minutes later, authorities received a call that police officers had been shot.\n\nFirst responders found the police officers \"gravely wounded\" in the road, Mr O'Dell said. \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Mr Trump, a staunch supporter of US law enforcement, tweeted early on Saturday.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, sheriff's officers responding to an attempted suicide call late Friday were confronted by a suspect firing a high-powered rifle, Director Mike Bruno told a news conference.\n\nTwo officers were shot in the exchange of gunfire, one hit in both hands and the other in the stomach, Mr Bruno said. The suspect was killed.\n\nAnd two Pennsylvania state troopers were shot Friday night, the agency said. \"Two state troopers shot and [the] suspect is deceased,\" Pennsylvania State Police spokeswoman Melinda Bondarenka told ABC News. \"We are not releasing any more details at this time.\"\n\nBoth troopers are expected to survive, ABC said of the shooting in the community of Fairchance, about 97 Richard \"Sam\" Howard were killed after they were shot while responding to a call related to a few suspicious people at 9:30 p.m. in the Florida city Friday night, the Orlando Sentinel reported. Baxter was pronounced dead at the scene. Howard succumbed to his injuries Saturday afternoon, the department said.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy,\" O'Dell said.\n\nPolice arrested Everett Glenn Miller, a 45-year-old Marine veteran, in the slayings. They found him at a nearby bar. Miller had recently been involuntarily committed by the Osceola County Sheriff's Office for mental health evaluation, under the state's Baker Act.\n\nThe police chief said it was too early to determine if the shooting was an ambush, but added it was \"leading toward that.\" Police said Howard and Baxter didn't return gunfire.\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted condolences following news of the shooting on Friday night.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the Kissimmee Police and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump wrote.\n\nTwo other officers were wounded in a separate shooting in Jacksonville, Fla., on Friday while responding to an attempted suicide call.\n\nJacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno said the officers arrived to find a man armed with a high-powered rifle when one officer was struck in both of his hands and the other was hit in his stomach as they exchanged gunfire with the suspect.\n\nThe suspect was also wounded in the shooting and died after being taken to a local hospital.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott offered prayers for the wounded Jacksonville officers as well as the two killed in the Kissimmee shooting.\n\nIn a third incident Friday, Pennsylvania State Police Trooper Melinda Bondarenka said two troopers were shot and a suspect was shot dead after police responded to an incident near a store on Friday night, NBC News reported.\n\nBondarenka said said both troopers were He was among the six police officers who were shot in three different cities in U.S. While two of the shootings took place at Kissimmee and Jacksonville in Florida, the third incident occurred at Fairchance in Pennsylvania, according to the respective agencies.\n\nTwo Kissimmee Police Department officers were shot on Friday at Mclaren Circle. According to Police Chief Jeff O'Dell, officer Matthew lost his life and Sgt. Sam Howard was in a critical condition, reports said. Kissimmee is located at around 23 kilometers (14 miles) south of Orlando, Florida.\n\nAccording to the police, both the officers were responding to a 911 call at 9:30 p.m. EDT. They were checking for suspicious people involving drug activity. The police did not confirm if they were ambushed, Washington Post reported. They said the officers might not have got a change to shoot back.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy. This is a tough time for each and every one of us,\" Police Chief Jeff O'Dell was quoted in media reports. Police made two arrests in relation to the incident and were looking for a third suspect.\n\nPresident Donald Trump too expressed grief over the incident on Twitter.\n\nIn another shooting in Florida, two officers were shot in Jacksonville during a gunfire exchange. While the condition of one of the officers was stable, the other one was said to be critical, reports said. One of the armed suspects was shot dead. According to JSO Director Mike Bruno, one of the officers was shot in stomach while the other one was shot in the hand, reports said.\n\nAt around 11:00 p.m. EDT, four to five officers responded to a call of attempted sucide at a home in Seaboard Avenue near Timuquana Road. On reaching the place, the officers heard gunfire shots. As they approached the house, the suspect started firing at them, after which they launched a counterattack, Bruno said.\n\nWhile two officers were injured during the counterattack, the suspect was shot dead.\n\nIn a third incident at Fairchance, Pennsylvania, two state police troopers were shot at, however, their injuries were not life threatening. The suspect in the incident was also killed, ABC News reported.\n\n\"Two state troopers shot and [the] suspect is deceased,\" Pennsylvania State Police spokeswoman Melinda Bondarenka told the news They did not have an opportunity to return fire, he said.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. When asked whether they were ambushed, he added, \"It's too early to tell, but it's leading that way.\"\n\nThree suspects were in custody and a fourth was being sought.\n\nTwo other police officers were shot and wounded in the Northern Florida city of Jacksonville while responding to reports of a shooter in an apartment.\n\n\"It's a tough time for law enforcement,\" O'Dell said of the Jacksonville shooting, adding that \"It's getting tough to do the job.\"\n\nFlorida Governor Rick Scott issued a statement on Twitter saying he was \"heartbroken,\" adding that \"we stand with ALL law enforcement in Florida.\"\n\nTensions have been high between police and minority communities in recent years following a spate of high-profile killings of unarmed African American men by white police and their subsequent acquittal.\n\nNumerous protests have been held against police brutality in the United States. At least three others have been brought in for questioning, but police have not released their names.\n\nKissimmee police are searching for a fourth person, but their name or a description of them has not been released. {"id": "10100030", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712014379", "source": {"id": "726", "title": "SunSentinel", "uri": "sun-sentinel.com"}, "url": "http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/os-kissimmee-police-shooting-folo-20170819-story.html", "body": "A second Kissimmee Police officer has died after a Friday night attack on law enforcement.\n\nSgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday from gunshot wounds he suffered when he and fellow officer Matthew Baxter were shot during a routine stop in the McLaren Circle area, according to department spokeswoman.\n\nBaxter died Friday night shortly after the shooting.\n\nBaxter was investigating three suspicious people about 9:30 p.m. near Palmway and Cypress streets when Howard came to help and a \"scuffle\" broke out. That's when police say Marine veteran Everett Glenn Miller, 45, shot the officers.\n\nInvestigators are still working to understand the details of what happened in the moments before the shooting, officials said.\n\nThe officers -- who were wearing body armor underneath their uniforms -- did not have a chance to return fire. O'Dell said \"it looked like they were surprised\" by the gunfire.\n\nMiller fled to Roscoe's Bar at 2344 N. Orange Blossom Trail, where Osceola County Sheriff's Office detectives found him about 11:30 p.m. When the officers approached him, Miller reached for his waistband -- but a fast-acting deputy tackled him to the ground and arrested him, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Extremely brave and heroic actions by the deputy, there were other people in the vicinity,\" O'Dell said. \"They went hands-on, tackled him to the ground and secured him [and] located a a 9mm and .22 revolver on his person.\"\n\nWhen officers took Miller to the Osceola County Jail Saturday, they placed Baxter's handcuffs on his wrists, O'Dell said.\n\nThe Sheriff's Office recently took Miller into custody under Florida's Baker Act, which allows involuntary commitment of people in mental health crises.\n\nO'Dell said the community needs to work with law enforcement. Social media posts showed Miller threatening law enforcement, O'Dell said, \"but we never got a call on that.''\n\nO'Dell said the news is especially difficult for members of his agency, as they must press forward while suffering the loss of a coworker and friend.\n\n\"We do not get to stop and cry for someone we've lost or mourn our hero,\" O'Dell said. \"At the time we go through it, the men and women of law enforcement are required to continue working and bring this individual to justice.\"\n\nBaxter, 27, was married to a fellow Kissimmee Police officer and had four young children, O'Dell said. Howard, 36, has one child.\n\n\"They are both wonderful men, family men. They are both very committed to the community,\" O'Dell said. \"They were the epitome of what you ask for in law enforcement officers.\"\n\nO'Dell praised other police agencies, including the Osceola and Orange sheriff's offices and Orlando Police Department, for their help.\n\n\"Everyone came to the scene without being asked,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe last Kissimmee officer killed on the job was shot in 1983.\n\nPresident Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence said on social media that their \"thoughts and prayers\" were with the Kissimmee Police.\n\nThe area where the shooting happened has historically been plagued by crime. O'Dell said Howard and Baxter were doing proactive police work there because it is known for drug sales. In 2008, law enforcement led a crackdown on drugs and violence that \"ravaged the McLaren Circle area,\" according to the U.S. Attorney's Office.\n\nOfficers arrested 19 people during that operation, and witnesses in subsequent court cases testified crime was so rampant that mobile businesses such as FedEx, UPS, pizza delivery and taxi services \"refused to enter the area to provide services to residents.\" Even the U.S. Postal Service stopped its route through the neighborhood for a time.\n\nKissimmee Police has more than 100 officers. O'Dell took over the department in August 2016.\n\nTwo Jacksonville police officers were also shot on the Westside of Jacksonville, according to the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. Two Pennsylvania Troopers were also reported shot late Friday.\n\nIt has also been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\ncdoornbos@orlandosentinel.com, 407-650-6931 or @CaitlinDoornbos\n\nTwo police officers shot in Kissimmee \"\n\nInteractive map: Every homicide in Central Florida \"", "dateTime": Police later arrested a suspect, whose name was not released.\n\nThe two officers were rushed to a hospital but one of the men, Officer Matthew Baxter, died of his injuries.\n\n\"Tonight we lost a brave officer - Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero,\" Florida Governor Rick Scott said on Twitter.\n\nThe other officer, Sergeant Sam Howard, was in \"grave, critical condition and the prognosis does not look good,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe neighbourhood where the shooting occurred has a problem with drug dealing, O'Dell said, and before the shooting the two officers approached the group of people to ask them questions.\n\nAside from the main suspect, police took two people at the scene into custody for questioning, he said.\n\nPresident Donald Trump said in a statement on Twitter, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones.\"\n\nIn another shooting in Jacksonville, Florida, a group of officers came under fire as they walked toward a house where a man with a high-powered rifle was threatening three people inside, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno told reporters.\n\nThe man opened fire through the door, then exited and exchanged gunfire with the officers from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office, wounding one officer in the hands and another officer in the stomach, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect, whose name was not released, was fatally shot in the gunfight, police said, and one officer was hospitalized in critical condition while the other was listed as stable.\n\nIn a third shooting, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect at a market in Fairchance, Pennsylvania, according to local media.\n\nThe suspect died, according to Pittsburgh television station WPXI, which cited unnamed police sources. {"id": "10021533", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 211, "label": "dmoz/Society/People/Men", "uri": "dmoz/Society/People/Men", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711798799", "source": {"id": "11259", "title": "Florida Today", "uri": "floridatoday.com"}, "url": "http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/2017/08/18/kissimmee-police-say-2-officers-shot/582579001/", "body": "72 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nTwo Kissimmee police officers were shot Friday night, one of them fatally, while responding to a suspicious person call in an area known for drug activity, according to Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nSgt. Sam Howard and Officer Matthew Baxter responded to Palmway and Cypress streets in Kissimmee at 9:27 p.m. and came into contact with four people, police said.\n\nMinutes later, at 9:32 p.m., both men were shot, O'Dell said.\n\n\"It looked like they were surprised,\" O'Dell said, adding that the officers did not return fire.\n\nOne of the officers was shot in the head at close range, a source told News 6. Both men were wearing their Kissimmee Police Department uniforms and body armor.\n\nOne man was taken into the custody after the shooting. O'Dell described the man as a \"strong suspect.\"\n\nO'Dell said it is believed that there was only one shooter using an unknown firearm, but did not say if that \"strong suspect\" is believed to be the shooter.\n\nAnother man was taken into custody after authorities found him in a bathroom at Roscoe's Bar, sources told News 6.\n\nThe Orange County Sheriff's Office said it is assisting law enforcement in Kissimmee.\n\nThe men and women of BCFR stand with our brothers and sisters in blue tonight as we mourn the loss of two Kissimmee Police Officers. -- BCFRpio (@BCFRpio)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nO'Dell said Baxter was a three-year veteran and Howard is a 10-year veteran. Both men are husbands and fathers.\n\n\"Right now, as you can imagine, (the families) are completely heartbroken and devastated,\" O'Dell said.\n\nUp until Friday night, it had been 34 years since a Kissimmee Police Department officer was killed in the line of duty.\n\nTwo officers were also shot in Jacksonville Friday night, according to News 6 partner WJXT. One officer is in stable condition and the other is in critical condition.\n\nThe Florida Highway Patrol issued an advisory warning drivers to stay out of the area near U.S. 192 and Orange Blossom Trail due to heavy police activity.\n\nNo other details were given. News 6 had a crew heading to the scene to gather more information.\n\nSkip in Skipx\n\nEmbed\n\nx\n\nShare\n\nCLOSE\n\nOn today's \"News in 90 Seconds,\" Rob Landers looks at Cocoa schools that were under lockdown, this morning's Atlas V launch and Harvey's rains. They did not have an opportunity to return fire.\n\nO'Dell says Baxter died later in a hospital, and Howard was in serious condition.\n\nAuthorities said three suspects are in custody and a fourth is being sought.\n\nThe Kissimmee Police Department said the two officers were shot in a downtown area, but did not immediately disclose further details.\n\nIn northern Florida, authorities say two police officers were shot in Jacksonsville. The Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said that the officers were shot in the west side of the city.\n\nIn a series of tweets, Florida Gov. {"id": "10118949", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 361, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712073784", "source": {"id": "8208", "title": "Central Maine", "uri": "centralmaine.com"}, "url": "http://www.centralmaine.com/2017/08/19/two-florida-police-officers-killed-2-injured-in-2-separate-shootings/", "body": "The first shooting happened Friday night in Kissimmee, just south of Orlando, and the second in Jacksonville.\n\nTwo officers were killed and two others were injured in two separate Florida shootings Friday night, outbreaks of violence against police that reverberated across the nation.\n\nThe first shooting happened in Kissimmee, just south of Orlando. Officers were responding to a report of suspicious activity in a high-crime area when they were taken by surprise, officials said.\n\nPolice Chief Jeff O'Dell discusses the shooting deaths of two police officers and the arrest of a suspect at a Saturday news conference in Kissimmee, Fla. Red Huber/Orlando Sentinel via AP Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nThe second shooting, about 90 minutes later in Jacksonville, left two officers injured. Police were dispatched to deal with an armed suicidal man when he came out firing.\n\nAll the shootings were \"deflating to law enforcement and heartbreaking,\" Kissimmee Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters, shortly after he announced that Officer Matthew Baxter had died of his injuries. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday, police announced on Facebook Saturday afternoon.\n\nAbout 9:30 p.m. Friday, Baxter and Howard were on patrol in a neighborhood in the north part of the city where police were trying to crack down on heightened drug activity.\n\nThe officers were searching several suspects when they got into a scuffle with one, who opened fire, O'Dell said at the news conference.\n\nThe officers didn't have time to return fire, O'Dell said. \"It looked like they were surprised by the gunfire.\"\n\nPolice began searching for the gunman and announced Saturday morning that they'd arrested Everett Miller, who is charged with murder.\n\nAs investigators learned more about Miller, O'Dell said he was disheartened to learn that the suspect had posted violent anti-police comments on social media and that no one had reported it to authorities. O'Dell didn't detail the comments.\n\nNearly two hours later and 165 miles north, police in Jacksonville were summoned to a home on the city's west side to defuse a situation involving a suicidal man armed with a gun, according to the Florida Times-Union.\n\nThere was an extra element of danger: Dispatchers told the officers that three other people were inside the home with the armed man.\n\nAs a team of officers approached the house, they heard gunshots and feared they were dealing with an active gunman.\n\nThe suspect came out firing a high-powered rifle, police said. He was killed during the ensuing firefight with officers and had not been identified Saturday.\n\nTwo officers were wounded, although their injuries were not life-threatening. The three other people in the house were uninjured.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? Richard \"Sam\" Howard was killed helping a fellow officer in the community he served for 10 years.\n\nThe Police Department reported \"with a heavy heart\" that Howard died Saturday afternoon, succumbing to his injuries from a double shooting the night before that rocked the law enforcement community nationwide.\n\nHoward, 36, was listed in \"grave condition\" overnight after he and fellow officer Matthew Baxter were shot in the line of duty about 9:30 p.m. Friday.\n\nThe shooting happened after Baxter initiated a routine check into three suspicious people near the intersection of Cypress and Palmway streets. Howard was in the area and went to back up Baxter when he heard his call, a Kissimmee Police spokeswoman said.\n\nAt some point during the exchange, 45-year-old Everette Glenn Miller pulled out a handgun and shot the two officers. They did not have time to fire back, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said.\n\nBaxter died shortly after the shooting.\n\nHoward was married and a father of one child, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said.\n\nHe was with the department for 10 years, and just received a promotion last month, according to the Kissimmee Police Department.\n\nKissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Baxter and Howard were the \"epitome\" of what officers should be.\n\n\"They're two wonderful men, family men,\" O'Dell said. \"They are two officers who are committed to doing it the right way. They are both very committed to the community.\"\n\nEverett Miller was arrested on a first degree murder charge related to the killings. He is being held at the Osceola County Jail.\n\nA prayer vigil will be held at the Hope Mission Church, 1431 Palmway St., at 3 p.m. Sunday. The church sits at the intersection where Howard and Baxter were shot.\n\nThe City of Kissimmee has set up an account with SunTrust Bank for individuals interested in donating to Howard and Baxter's families. NPR reports that Officer Matthew Baxter was killed and Sgt. Sam Howard remains in \"grave critical condition\" after responding to an incident in central Kissimmee, Fla., Friday evening. Per CNN, the officers were caught off guard by gunfire when responding to a suspicious activity call. They were unable to return fire in the possible ambush. Florida Gov. Rick Scott called Baxter, a father of three and three-year veteran on the force, a hero, tweeting: \"Tonight we lost a brave officer - Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero. Praying for @kissimmeepolice\"; President Trump also sent condolences over social media after the news broke. Kissimmee police have three suspects in custody and are searching for another.\n\n\"This is a tough time for each one of us,\" Kissimmee Chief Jeff O'Dell said, asking the public to keep the police department and the families of the fallen officers in our \"thoughts and prayers.\" In a separate incident 165 miles north of Kissimmee in Jacksonville, Fla., two officers responding to an attempted suicide call Friday night were shot. The suspect began shooting the responding officers through a door with a \"high powered rifle\" before exchanging gunfire outside. The suspect was shot and died later at the hospital; one injured officer is in critical condition, the other in stable condition. Meanwhile, NPR reports that two state troopers serving a warrant in Pennsylvania Friday were shot. No updates on their condition, but they were said to be \"alert and conscious\" after the shooting occurred, when one was flown to a nearby hospital while the other was transported by ambulance.", {"id": "10057571", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711897446", "source": {"id": "2104", "title": "mprnews.org", "uri": "mprnews.org"}, "url": "https://www.mprnews.org/story/2017/08/19/6-police-officers-shot-in-separate-incidents-in-florida-pennsylvania", "body": "Updated at 2:40 a.m. ET Saturday\n\nPolice in Kissimmee, Fla., just south of Orlando, reported late Friday that two officers there had been shot.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter, a 3-year veteran of the department, was killed, and Sgt. Sam Howard, a 10-year veteran, was in \"grave critical condition,\" Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters early Saturday.\n\nBaxter was married to another officer and had three children. Howard is also married and a father.\n\nOrange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs had earlier written on Twitter that both had been killed, calling the shooting a \"[h]eartbreaking loss of two of Kissimmee's finest officers.\"\n\nPresident Trump sent his condolences to the officers on Twitter:\n\nPolice believe there was one shooter; they have a \"strong suspect\" in custody, along with two others and are still looking for one other person, O'Dell said.\n\n\"This is a tough time for each one of us,\" the chief told reporters. O'Dell said the department hasn't \"experienced this in over 25 years.\"\n\n\"At this point I'd ask you to please keep the men and women of the Kissimmee Police Department, the families of the fallen officers, the law enforcement personnel in the central Florida area in your thoughts and prayers,\" he added.\n\nThe officers were shot in an area with \"some drug activity,\" he said.\n\n\"There are no county or jurisdiction lines when it comes to our Law Enforcement Brotherhood,\" Osceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. wrote in response to the shootings.\n\nLater in the same night, two other officers were shot in a separate incident about 165 miles north, in Jacksonville, Fla.\n\nThe Jacksonville Sheriff's Office wrote that one of the officers was in critical condition and one was in stable condition in local hospitals.\n\nMike Bruno, the director the office's Department of Patrol and Enforcement, told reporters that four or five officers responded to an \"attempted suicide call\" at a home around 11 p.m. They thought it was an active shooter situation after hearing gunshots from inside.\n\nA suspect \"began shooting through the door at the officers,\" using a \"high-powered rifle,\" then went outside and exchanged gunfire with the officers, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect was shot by police and died at a hospital.\n\nIn a third separate incident, in southwest Pennsylvania, two Pennsylvania state troopers were shot in Fairchance Friday. The suspect in that incident was also killed.\n\nKDKA has more:\n\nState police say both troopers were alert and conscious after the shooting. One trooper was flown to a nearby hospital, and another was transported by ambulance.\n\nSources tell KDKA that one trooper was shot in the stomach and was in surgery at a hospital in Morgantown around 10:30 p.m. Sources say the other trooper was shot in the hand.\n\nSources say troopers were serving a warrant when the shooting broke out.\n\nCopyright 2017 NPR.", "dateTime": Howard was in grave condition until he died Saturday afternoon, according to the police department.\n\n\"I am so proud of the sworn and civilian members of our department by acting quickly to identify the suspect and bring him to justice. (WOFL FOX 35) - The Kissimmee Police Department said two of their officers were shot in a downtown area on Friday night. One of those officers has died and the other is left gravely injured, according to Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell.\n\nFOX 35 had earlier reported that both officers had died, based on information our reporters were receiving from those close to the investigation into the shootings.\n\nThe shootings happened as the two officers were responding to a call at the intersection of Palmway and Cypress streets, around 9 p.m. on Friday.\n\nAn active search continued into Saturday morning for a suspect who remained at large. The Florida Highway Patrol advised drivers to avoid the area of U.S. 192 and Orange Blossom Trail, due to a heavy police presence.\n\nThere was a second scene where several police officers gathered, near Roscoe's Bar & Packaging, at 2344 N Orange Blossom Trail. No details were given as to their presence at that location.\n\nThe two officers were responding to a call of suspicious activity around 9 p.m., Chief O'Dell said during a news conference.\n\n\"At approximately 9:32, we received our first call... that our officers were shot,\" he said.\n\nO'Dell said other responding Officers found the two officers on the roadway, when they arrived at the scene.\n\nFOX 35 reporters were first told that one officer was taken to Osceola Regional Medical Center and the other to Orlando Regional Medical Center. Chief O'Dell later clarified that both were taken to Osceola Regional.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter, who had served three years with the force, died from his injuries, O'Dell said. Sgt. Sam Howard, 10-year veteran, remained in critical condition.\n\nChief O'Dell said there are four suspects in total. Three had been taken into custody and one was still being sought early Saturday.\n\n\"I can't divulge any information about that, as this is an ongoing investigation,\" he added.\n\nHe told reporters that it has been a dark day for his colleagues as they try to cope with this tragedy.\n\n\"These were beloved fathers and husbands and sons,\" said O'Dell. \"We haven't experienced this in over 25 years.\"\n\nBefore details of the shootings were immediately known, community leaders and other law enforcement officers began sending condolences over Twitter. This was before it was learned that one officer had died and the other was in critical condition.\n\n\"Heartbreaking loss of two of Kissimmee's finest officers. Please join in prayers for families, friends, and law enforcement,\" Orange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs tweeted.\n\n\"Sending out prayers,\" tweeted Orlando Police Chief John Mina.\n\nThe Winter Park Police Department echoed the sentiment, \"We stand with our brothers and sisters at the Kissimmee Police Department. Our thoughts and prayers are with everyone involved.\"\n\n\"Hard night to look at Twitter. Just want to reach through the screen and comfort the families -- our Family,\" posted Volusia County Sheriff Mike Chitwood.\n\nEarly Saturday, President Donald Trump tweeted, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\"\n\nLess than an hour after two police officers were killed in Kissimmee, Florida, reports of two officers being shot in Jacksonville. (AP)\n\nA suspect has been arrested and charged in the shooting death of a Florida police officer and serious wounding of another officer late Friday.\n\nEverett Glen Miller, 45, was charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death of Officer Matthew Baxter, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said Saturday in a news conference. He could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard.\n\nHoward, who was also shot after a scuffle with Miller, is in critical condition. O'Dell said he does not expect Howard to survive from his injuries.\n\nO'Dell said it does not appear that Miller, a Marine veteran, has an extensive criminal history but authorities are still investigating.\n\nTOTAL OF 6 POLICE OFFICERS SHOT IN FLORIDA, PENNSYLVANIA\n\nThe two officers were in the Palmway and Cypress area of Kissimmee checking out a report of a suspicious person at approximately 9:27 p.m. Soon afterward, a 911 call came in, saying the officers had been shot, O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers did not return fire, and it appears they were surprised, the police chief said, adding that authorities are still talking to witnesses to determine the timeline of events.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions were taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but O'Dell said no others arrests were anticipated.\n\nPOLICE OFFICER SHOT IN NEW YORK CITY RESPONDING TO CALL\n\n\"We've got to come together as a nation and get our community involved,\" O'Dell said of the police shooting.\n\nBoth officers are husbands and have children. Baxter was married to another Kissimmee police officer.\n\nO'Dell said he has been in contact with Florida Gov. Rick Scott and Attorney General Pam Bondi. President Donald Trump tweeted early Friday: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you! \"\n\nAlso on Friday night, two police officers were shot in Jacksonville, Fla., and two state troopers were shot in Pennsylvania. He could face other charges for the wounding of Sgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard.\n\nHoward, who was also shot after a scuffle with Miller, is in critical condition. O'Dell said he does not expect Howard to survive from his injuries.\n\nO'Dell said it does not appear that Miller, a Marine veteran, has an extensive criminal history but authorities are still investigating.\n\nTOTAL OF 6 POLICE OFFICERS SHOT IN FLORIDA, PENNSYLVANIA\n\nThe two officers were in the Palmway and Cypress area of Kissimmee checking out a report of a suspicious person at approximately 9:27 p.m. Soon afterward, a 911 call came in, saying the officers had been shot, O'Dell said.\n\nThe officers did not return fire, and it appears they were surprised, the police chief said, adding that authorities are still talking to witnesses to determine the timeline of events.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions were taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but O'Dell said no others arrests were anticipated.\n\nPOLICE OFFICER SHOT IN NEW YORK CITY RESPONDING TO CALL\n\n\"We've got to come together as a nation and get our community involved,\" O'Dell said of the police shooting.\n\nBoth officers are husbands and have children. Baxter was married to another Kissimmee police officer.\n\nO'Dell said he has been in contact with Florida Gov. Rick Scott and Attorney General Pam Bondi. President Donald Trump tweeted early Friday: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you! \"\n\nAlso on Friday night, two police officers were shot in Jacksonville, Fla., and two state troopers were shot in Pennsylvania. The other officer, 10-year veteran Sgt. Sam Howard, is in \"grave critical condition and the prognosis does not look good,\" O'Dell said.\n\nGov. Rick Scott erroneously tweeted late Friday night that both officers had died.\n\nOne of the four suspects remains on the run. The officers were investigating suspicious persons.\n\nPresident Trump reacted to the Kissimmee shootings, tweeting, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. Scott tweeted, \"Our prayers are with all of @kissimmeepolice & their loved ones.\"\n\nA subsequent tweet read, \"Our law enforcement officers are true heroes and we will miss these brave Floridians.\"\n\nKissimmee is located about about 23 miles south of Orlando.\n\nIn northeastern Florida, two officers were shot, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office announced.\n\nOne officer is in critical condition and the other is in stable condition, the Sheriff's Office said.\n\nOfficials said the suspect was shot and killed by officers.\n\n\"Praying for these officers who were shot tonight,\" Gov. Scott said of the Jacksonville officer\n\nAnd in reference to both Florida shootings, Gov. Officers were responding to a report of suspicious activity in a high-crime area when they were taken by surprise, officials said.\n\nThe second shooting, about 90 minutes later in Jacksonville, left two officers injured. Police were dispatched to deal with an armed suicidal man when he came out firing.\n\nAll the shootings were \"deflating to law enforcement and heartbreaking,\" Kissimmee Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters, shortly after he announced that Officer Matthew Baxter had died of his injuries. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday, police announced on Facebook Saturday afternoon.\n\nAbout 9:30 p.m. Friday, Baxter and Howard were on patrol in a neighborhood in the north part of the city where police were trying to crack down on heightened drug activity.\n\nThe officers were searching several suspects when they got into a scuffle with one, who opened fire, O'Dell said at the news conference.\n\nThe officers didn't have time to return fire, O'Dell said. \"It looked like they were surprised by the gunfire.\"\n\nPolice began searching for the shooter and announced Saturday morning that they'd arrested Everett Miller, who is charged with murder.\n\nAs investigators learned more about Miller, O'Dell said he was disheartened to learn that the suspect had posted violent anti-police comments on social media and that no one had reported it to authorities. O'Dell didn't detail the comments.\n\nNearly two hours later and 165 miles north, police officers in Jacksonville were summoned to a home on the city's west side to defuse a situation involving a suicidal man armed with a gun, according to the Florida Times-Union. There was an extra element of danger: Dispatchers told the officers three other people were inside the home with the armed man.\n\nAs a team of officers approached the house, they heard gunshots and feared they were dealing with an active shooter.\n\nThe suspect came out firing a high-powered rifle, police said. He was killed during the ensuing firefight with officers and had not been identified early Saturday.\n\nTwo officers were wounded, though their injuries are not life-threatening. The three other people in the house were okay.\n\nAnd around 8 p.m. Friday, two Pennsylvania State troopers were shot southeast of Pittsburgh after stopping a man who had an outstanding warrant, according to Pittsburgh ABC-affiliate WPVI. Matthew Baxter were shot when they responded to a call in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets around 9:30 p.m. Friday.\n\nBaxter, a 3-year veteran of the department was pronounced dead shortly after the shooting and Howard, a 10-year veteran, succumbed to his wounds Saturday afternoon, O'Dell said.\n\nO'Dell said Everett Milller has been arrested and charged in the death of Baxter. Additional charges He will be transferred to the Osceola County Jail Saturday in Baxter's handcuffs, O'Dell said.\n\nMiller was arrested around 11:30 p.m. at Roscoe's Bar on Orange Blossom Trail, in Kissimmee, police said. Sam Howard were responding to a suspicious person report in Kissimmee, Florida and were shot nearly five minutes after arriving on the scene while performing a routine check. Both officers were transported to Osceola Regional Medical Center. Baxter, who had served at the Kissimmee Police Department for three years, died at the hospital. Sgt. Howard, who has been with the KPD for a decade, remains in critical condition, officials said.\n\nDuring a news conference, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said the police department is looking into whether the two were ambushed. The outlet reported that three suspects have been arrested in connection with the shooting and the KPD is still searching for the fourth.\n\nKissimmee Mayor Jose Alvarez released a statement about Baxter -- who was a father of three -- and Sgt. Howard. \"The entire city of Kissimmee is in mourning. We pray for all law enforcement who are out there, protecting our community,\" said Alvarez, according to the source.\n\nMiles away in Jacksonville, Florida two officers who were responding to a report of an attempted suicide were shot through the doorway of a house when they arrived on the scene. Police officials said there was an exchange of gunfire and the alleged suspect was killed, the outlet reported.\n\nThe New York Daily News said that two troopers were shot during an incident outside of a supermarket in Fayette County, Pennsylvania. According to the outlet, both troopers were hospitalized and remain in stable condition, and the suspect was reportedly killed.\n\nFriends & Colleagues Honor Slain Black Female NYPD Officer", {"id": "10011054", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711760985", "source": {"id": "883", "title": "Orlando Sentinel", "uri": "orlandosentinel.com"}, "url": "http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/breaking-news/os-kissimmee-police-shot-20170818-story.html", "body": "Two Kissimmee Police officers were shot and killed Friday night, and one person was taken into custody.\n\nThe department reported on Friday night that two of its officers were shot in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets. Osceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. confirmed that both officers died.\n\nOrange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs asked for prayers for families of the officers and said it was a \"heartbreaking loss of two of Kissimmee's finest officers.\"\n\nOne person was in custody, according to Florida Highway Patrol spokeswoman Sgt. Kim Montes\n\nThe officers were in a neighborhood near Orange Blossom Trail and John Young Parkway when they were injured, according to the Osceola County Sheriff's Office.\n\nIt's unclear whether the officers were responding to a call in the area when they were injured.\n\nHawkins said he couldn't believe the news.\n\n\"It's just awful. We're praying for the families of these officers and for the whole KPD family,\" he said.\n\nHawkins said the last officer killed on the job was in 1993 after being shot.\n\nInformation about the suspect was not immediately provided\n\nFHP said there was \"heavy police activity\" in the area and told people to avoid the area.\n\nAlexis Nieves, 27, was driving to see a friend when she got stopped at a red light on Orange Blossom Trail and U.S. Highway 192.\n\nShe saw a few cop cars then dozens started arriving to the intersection. She looked to her left and saw an officer with a long gun, the she saw a person being loaded into an ambulance. There were helicopters circling the in the area.\n\nEmergency crews were doing CPR and trying to resuscitate the person. Nieves didn't know it was an officer who had been shot.\n\n\"I just started crying,\" she said. \"I didn't know what to think. It's so sad.\"\n\nOn its Twitter account, the Orlando Police Department said, \"Please keep @kissimmeepolice in your prayers tonight.\"\n\nThe Orange County Sheriff's Office also offered its own message of comfort, saying, \"Our solidarity is with @kissimmeepolice as they deal with this tragic loss.\"\n\nSanford Police also sent a healing message: \"Our hearts are heavy with the news of our 2 fallen @kissimmeepolice Officers. OUr prayers are with their families & their fellow officers.\"\n\nKissimmee Police has 104 officers. Chief Jeff O'Dell took over the department in August 2016. He was expected to make a statement, but had not made one as of press time late Friday night.\n\nIt has been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\nOn Friday night, there was also a report from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office that two police officers had been shot on the Westside of Jacksonville.\n\nThis is a breaking news report. Minutes later, Kissimmee Police dispatch received word that the officers had been shot at, police Chief Jeffrey O'Dell said in a press conference.\n\nKissimmee residents often \"get tired of putting up with some of the drug dealing and nonsense that goes on in the neighborhood\" and call the police to come check it out, O'Dell said.\n\nThe two responding officers, Matthew Baxter and Sam Howard, arrived at the scene and spoke with three individuals when a fourth person arrived and began shooting. The officers were not able to shoot back.\n\n\"They were surprised,\" O'Dell said. \"It's too early to tell\" O'Dell said when asked if it was an ambush, but added \"it's leading that way.\"\n\nBoth sustained injuries from gunshots. Baxter later died from his injuries and Howard is in grave condition, Kissimmee police department said on Twitter.\n\nAt least two people were taken into custody and police are looking for a third suspect.\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted his condolences around 1:30 a.m. Saturday.\n\nThe area where the cops were shot, about 20 miles south of Orlando is known for having drug activity. The shooting death of officer Baxter is the first time a Kissimmee police officer has been killed on the job since 1983, the Orlando Sentinel reports.\n\nFollow Thomas Phippen on Twitter\n\nSend tips {"id": "10132330", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-20", "uri": "712115272", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/6-police-officers-shot-three-090335515.html", "body": "One police officer of Kissimmee Police Department died Friday after he was shot at Mclaren Circle in the city. He was among the six police officers who were shot in three different cities in U.S. While two of the shootings took place at Kissimmee and Jacksonville in Florida, the third incident occurred at Fairchance in Pennsylvania, according to the respective agencies.\n\nTwo Kissimmee Police Department officers were shot on Friday at Mclaren Circle. According to Police Chief Jeff O'Dell, officer Matthew lost his life and Sgt. Sam Howard was in a critical condition, reports said. Kissimmee is located at around 23 kilometers (14 miles) south of Orlando, Florida.\n\nAccording to the police, both the officers were responding to a 911 call at 9:30 p.m. EDT. They were checking for suspicious people involving drug activity. The police did not confirm if they were ambushed, Washington Post reported. They said the officers might not have got a change to shoot back.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy. This is a tough time for each and every one of us,\" Police Chief Jeff O'Dell was quoted in media reports. Police made two arrests in relation to the incident and were looking for a third suspect.\n\nPresident Donald Trump too expressed grief over the incident on Twitter.\n\nIn another shooting in Florida, two officers were shot in Jacksonville during a gunfire exchange. While the condition of one of the officers was stable, the other one was said to be critical, reports said. One of the armed suspects was shot dead. According to JSO Director Mike Bruno, one of the officers was shot in stomach while the other one was shot in the hand, reports said.\n\nAt around 11:00 p.m. EDT, four to five officers responded to a call of attempted sucide at a home in Seaboard Avenue near Timuquana Road. On reaching the place, the officers heard gunfire shots. As they approached the house, the suspect started firing at them, after which they launched a counterattack, Bruno said.\n\nWhile two officers were injured during the counterattack, the suspect was shot dead.\n\nIn a third incident at Fairchance, Pennsylvania, two state police troopers were shot at, however, their injuries were not life threatening. The suspect in the incident was also killed, ABC News reported.\n\n\"Two state troopers shot and [the] suspect is deceased,\" Pennsylvania State Police spokeswoman Melinda Bondarenka told the news outlet. \"We are not releasing any more details at this time.\"\n\nRelated Articles\n\n3 Killed, Including Gunman, In Florida Shooting3 Shot Dead At Great Lakes Dragaway In Kenosha County",
