{"id": "10116759", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 361, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712066916", "source": {"id": "1378", "title": "Portland Press Herald", "uri": "pressherald.com"}, "url": "http://www.pressherald.com/2017/08/19/two-florida-police-officers-killed-two-injured-in-shootings/", "body": "One of the suspects had posted violent anti-police comments on social media and no one reported it.\n\nTwo officers were killed and two others were injured in two separate Florida shootings Friday night, outbreaks of violence against police that reverberated across the nation.\n\nThe first shooting happened in Kissimmee, just south of Orlando. Officers were responding to a report of suspicious activity in a high-crime area when they were taken by surprise, officials said.\n\nPolice Chief Jeff O'Dell discusses the shooting deaths of two police officers and the arrest of a suspect at a Saturday news conference in Kissimmee, Fla. Red Huber/Orlando Sentinel via AP Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nThe second shooting, about 90 minutes later in Jacksonville, left two officers injured. Police were dispatched to deal with an armed suicidal man when he came out firing.\n\nAll the shootings were \"deflating to law enforcement and heartbreaking,\" Kissimmee Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters, shortly after he announced that Officer Matthew Baxter had died of his injuries. Sgt. Sam Howard died Saturday, police announced on Facebook Saturday afternoon.\n\nAbout 9:30 p.m. Friday, Baxter and Howard were on patrol in a neighborhood in the north part of the city where police were trying to crack down on heightened drug activity.\n\nThe officers were searching several suspects when they got into a scuffle with one, who opened fire, O'Dell said at the news conference.\n\nThe officers didn't have time to return fire, O'Dell said. \"It looked like they were surprised by the gunfire.\"\n\nPolice began searching for the gunman and announced Saturday morning that they'd arrested Everett Miller, who is charged with murder.\n\nAs investigators learned more about Miller, O'Dell said he was disheartened to learn that the suspect had posted violent anti-police comments on social media and that no one had reported it to authorities. O'Dell didn't detail the comments.\n\nNearly two hours later and 165 miles north, police in Jacksonville were summoned to a home on the city's west side to defuse a situation involving a suicidal man armed with a gun, according to the Florida Times-Union.\n\nThere was an extra element of danger: Dispatchers told the officers that three other people were inside the home with the armed man.\n\nAs a team of officers approached the house, they heard gunshots and feared they were dealing with an active gunman.\n\nThe suspect came out firing a high-powered rifle, police said. He was killed during the ensuing firefight with officers and had not been identified Saturday.\n\nTwo officers were wounded, although their injuries were not life-threatening. The three other people in the house were uninjured.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? Our daily headlines email is delivered each morning. Officer Sam Howard is in very grave condition. pic.twitter.com/oXypORJaIn -- Kissimmee Police (@kissimmeepolice)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nTwo Pennsylvania State Police troopers were shot in Fayette County, south of Pittsburgh on the border with West Virginia and Maryland.\n\nOne trooper was shot in the stomach and the other in the hand, according to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette; both were in stable condition. The suspect was shot and killed.\n\nThe paper reported the troopers saw a man they believed was wanted on a warrant. The troopers stopped the suspect, and he then reached into his backpack, pulled out a gun and started shooting, according to the paper.\n\nA press conference is set for 10:30 a.m. in that incident.\n\nTwo Jacksonville police officers were shot responding to a suicidal person, WFTV reports.\n\nOfficers arriving to the home heard gunfire and, as they approached the house, the suspect began firing through a door, the station reports. Officials said one officer was in critical condition and the other in stable condition.\n\nThe sheriff's department said on its official Twitter account that the suspect was also shot, and died at the {"id": "10069958", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 122, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711932451", "source": {"id": "597", "title": "The Baltimore Sun", "uri": "baltimoresun.com"}, "url": "http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/nation-world/os-kissimmee-police-shot-20170818-story.html", "body": "A Marine veteran has been arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death on Friday of a Kissimmee Police officer, and there is \"not much hope\" a second officer he's accused of shooting will survive, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said this morning.\n\nPolice arrested 45-year-old Everett Glenn Miller Saturday morning in the shooting. O'Dell said the Osceola County Sheriff's Office recently took Miller into custody under Florida's Baker Act, which allows involuntary commitment of people in mental health crises.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter was killed and Sgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard was shot and is in grave condition, O'Dell said. The uniformed officers were investigating three suspicious people in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets about 9:30 p.m. Five minutes later, dispatchers received the first call reporting the officers had been shot.\n\nThe officers did not have time to return fire. O'Dell said \"it looked like they were surprised\" by the gunfire.\n\nO'Dell said Miller fled to Roscoe's Bar at 2344 N Orange Blossom Trail, where he was later arrested.\n\nBaxter, 27, was married to a fellow Kissimmee Police officer, with whom he shared three young children, O'Dell said. Howard, 36, has one child.\n\n\"They are both wonderful men, family men. They are both very committed to the community,\" O'Dell said. \"They were the epitome of what you ask for in law enforcement officers.\"\n\nBaxter and Howard were wearing body armor underneath their uniforms when they were shot, O'Dell said. Howard is a 10-year veteran of the department and Baxter had been with the Kissimmee department for three years.\n\nAs of 9 a.m. Saturday, Howard remained in critical condition; O'Dell said there was \"not much hope that he will survive this.\"\n\nMiller, who had two guns -- a 9mm and .22 revolver -- was taken into custody about 11:30 p.m. Friday. O'Dell said officers plan to put Baxter's handcuffs on Miller when they take him to the Osceola County Jail Saturday.\n\nO'Dell said he did not expect to make any additional arrests.\n\n\"This is a tough time for each and every one of us,\" O'Dell said.\n\nO'Dell said the community needs to work with law enforcement. Social media posts showed Miller threatening law enforcement, O'Dell said, \"but we never got a call on that.''\n\nOsceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. said he couldn't believe the news.\n\n\"It's just awful. We're praying for the families of these officers and for the whole KPD family,\" he said.\n\nThe last officer killed on the job was shot 1983.\n\nCarlos Santiago, 37, was driving with his wife and daughter back from dinner on International Drive on Friday night when they saw dozens of patrol cars speed past them on Orange Blossom Trail.\n\n\"They were just flying,\" he said. \"It was pretty obvious something bad had happened.\"\n\nThe area where the shooting happened is in McLaren Circle, which has historically been plagued by crime. O'Dell said Howard and Baxter were doing proactive police work there because it is known for drug sales. In 2008, law enforcement led a crackdown on drugs and violence that \"ravaged the McLaren Circle area,\" according to the U.S. Attorney's Office.\n\nOfficers arrested 19 people during that operation, and witnesses in subsequent court cases testified crime was so rampant that mobile businesses such as FedEx, UPS, pizza delivery and taxi services \"refused to enter the area to provide services to residents.\" Even the U.S. Postal Service stopped its route through the neighborhood for a time.\n\n\"It's fairly well known as not a great area. It's pretty rundown compared to the rest of the city and it's known for having more crime,\" Santiago said.\n\nWhile the media waited for O'Dell to address the public in front of the emergency entrance at Osceola Regional Medical Center on Friday night, two women were being escorted out of the building by two police officers. They were both crying and huddled before they saw the lights and cameras outside and dashed back into the building.\n\nAt least four Osceola deputies were stationed by the south entrance to the hospital, wearing body armor and carrying heavy guns, standing next to their patrol cars.\n\nAlexis Nieves, 27, was driving to see a friend when she got stopped at a red light on Orange Blossom Trail and U.S. Highway 192.\n\nShe saw a few cop cars then dozens started arriving to the intersection. She looked to her left and saw an officer with a long gun, the she saw a person being loaded into an ambulance. There were helicopters circling the in the area.\n\nEmergency crews were doing CPR and trying to resuscitate the person. Nieves didn't know it was an officer who had been shot.\n\n\"I just started crying,\" she said. \"I didn't know what to think. It's so sad.\"\n\nNieves said she saw said more than 80 law enforcement vehicles flooding the area, along with fire trucks and EMS vehicles.\n\n\"I was in the middle of it all and couldn't believe what was happening,\" she said. \"I called my friend in tears. I've never seen anything like that.\"\n\nMessages of support flowed out from across the country.\n\nOn its Twitter account, the Orlando Police Department said, \"Please keep @kissimmeepolice in your prayers tonight.\"\n\nThe Orange County Sheriff's Office also offered its own message of comfort, saying, \"Our solidarity is with @kissimmeepolice as they deal with this tragic loss.\"\n\nO'Dell praised other police agencies, including the Osceola and Orange sheriff's offices and Orlando Police Department, for their help.\n\n\"Everyone came to the scene without being asked. We don't get to stop for a minute and cry for somebody we've lost or mourn a hero at the time we're going through it.\"\n\nKissimmee Police has 104 officers. O'Dell took over the department in August 2016.\n\nOn Friday night, there was also a report from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office that two police officers had been shot on the Westside of Jacksonville. Two Pennsylvania Troopers were also reported shot late Friday.\n\nThe shootings received nationwide attention, with President Donald Trump sending thoughts and prayers to the Kissimmee Police.\n\nIt has been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\nEarlier reports Friday night from official sources indicated that two officers had died.\n\nStaff Writers Bianca Padro Ocasio, Christal Hayes, Krista Torralva and Gal Tziperman Lotan contributed to this report.\n\ncdoornbos@orlandosentinel.com, 407-650-6931 or @CaitlinDoornbos\n\nRead more about this story in our e-edition at OrlandoSentinel.com/late or on our website.\n\nInteractive map: Every homicide in Central Florida \"", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T14:32:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 5722, "textStart": 5711, "date": "2016-08-", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "dateCrawl": {"id": "10013385", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711767576", "source": {"id": "1697", "title": "Chicago Tribune", "uri": "chicagotribune.com"}, "url": "http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/os-kissimmee-police-shot-20170818-story.html", "body": "Two Kissimmee Police officers were shot and killed Friday night in McLaren Circle, and at least one person was taken into custody.\n\nThe department reported on Friday night that two of its officers were shot in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets. Osceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. confirmed that both officers died.\n\nOrange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs asked for prayers for families of the officers and said it was a \"heartbreaking loss of two of Kissimmee's finest officers.\"\n\nOne person was in custody, sources said.\n\nThe officers were in a neighborhood near Orange Blossom Trail and John Young Parkway when they were injured, according to the Osceola County Sheriff's Office.\n\nIt's unclear whether the officers were responding to a call in the area when they were injured.\n\nHawkins said he couldn't believe the news.\n\n\"It's just awful. We're praying for the families of these officers and for the whole KPD family,\" he said.\n\nHawkins said the last officer killed on the job was in 1993 after being shot.\n\nInformation about the person in custody was not immediately provided.\n\nCarlos Santiago, 37, was driving with his wife and daughter back from dinner on International Drive when they saw dozens of patrol cars speed past them on Orange Blossom Trail.\n\n\"They were just flying,\" he said. \"It was pretty obvious something bad had happened.\"\n\nThe area where the shooting happened is in McLaren Circle.\n\n\"It's fairly well known as not a great area. It's pretty run down compared to the rest of the city and it's known for having more crime,\" Santiago said.\n\nFHP said there was \"heavy police activity\" in the area and told people to avoid the area. There was also a large police presence at Roscoe's late Friday.\n\nAlexis Nieves, 27, was driving to see a friend when she got stopped at a red light on Orange Blossom Trail and U.S. Highway 192.\n\nShe saw a few cop cars then dozens started arriving to the intersection. She looked to her left and saw an officer with a long gun, the she saw a person being loaded into an ambulance. There were helicopters circling the in the area.\n\nEmergency crews were doing CPR and trying to resuscitate the person. Nieves didn't know it was an officer who had been shot.\n\n\"I just started crying,\" she said. \"I didn't know what to think. It's so sad.\"\n\nNieves said she saw said more than 80 law enforcement vehicles flooding the area, along with fire trucks and EMS vehicles.\n\n\"I was in the middle of it all and couldn't believe what was happening,\" she said. \"I called my friend in tears. I've never seen anything like that.\"\n\nOn its Twitter account, the Orlando Police Department said, \"Please keep @kissimmeepolice in your prayers tonight.\"\n\nThe Orange County Sheriff's Office also offered its own message of comfort, saying, \"Our solidarity is with @kissimmeepolice as they deal with this tragic loss.\"\n\nSanford Police also sent a healing message: \"Our hearts are heavy with the news of our 2 fallen @kissimmeepolice Officers. OUr prayers are with their families & their fellow officers.\"\n\nKissimmee Police has 104 officers. Chief Jeff O'Dell took over the department in August 2016. He was expected to make a statement, but had not made one as of press time late Friday night.\n\nIt has been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\nOn Friday night, there was also a report from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office that two police officers had been shot on the Westside of Jacksonville.\n\nThis is a breaking news report. Check back for updates.\n\nStaff Writers Bianca Padro Ocasio, Christal Hayes, Krista Torralva and Gal Tziperman Lotan contribute to this report.\n\njareddick@orlandosentinel.com, 407-420-5268 or The incident took place late on Friday in Kissimmee community, south of Orlando.\n\nBaxter and his colleague Sergeant Sam Howard approached a group of people to question them based on suspicion they might be involved in some illegal activity, Kissimmee police chief Jeff O'Dell said.\n\nHowever, they seemed to have been taken by surprise when they were shot by the group, O'Dell said.\n\nWhile Baxter died, Howard was in \"grave, critical condition and the prognosis does not look good\", Reuters cited the chief as saying.\n\nHe said the two officials were called to the incident site to investigate suspicious activity, which according to reports is about drug dealing.\n\nFour people are reported to have been involved in the incident. Withing minutes both were shot - Baxter died of his wounds and Howard is in \"grave, critical condition.\"\n\nPolice arrested three people following the shooting, and are searching for a fourth person.\n\n\"At this time, we have a strong suspect in custody that we are interviewing,\" O'Dell said.\n\nFollowing the news of the shooting, President Donald Trump tweeted his condolences.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" the President said.\n\nFlorida Gov. Rick Scott described Baxter as a husband, a father and a hero.\n\n\"Heartbroken to hear loss of @kissimmeepolice officer Matthew Baxter. Praying for a quick recovery for officer in critical condition,\" Scott.\n\nFor the record, this is the MO of previous police ambushes. The suspect or suspect is reported as a \"suspicious person\" and when the police arrive to investigate, they're gunned down.\n\nAlthough 3 suspects are in custody, authorities have yet to identify the race of the killers. Somehow, you have to believe that if they were white supremacists, it would be all over the national news.\n\nElsewhere, 2 police officers were shot in Jacksonville, FL confronting a suicidal man. Two other officers were shot in Fayette County, Pennslvania.\n\nNBC News:\n\nIn Jacksonville, police officers were responding to a call about an attempted suicide at a house. Gunfire was heard from outside the property as officers arrived, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director of Patrol and Enforcement Mike Bruno told NBC News.\n\nBefore officers even entered the house, the suspect began shooting at them through the doorway and there was an exchange of gunfire in which two officers were struck, one of them in the stomach, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect is dead and it's not yet known if body cameras were worn or activated.\n\nIn Pennsylvania, two troopers were shot and a suspect killed after an incident near a store on West Church Street, Fairchance, Fayette County, Pennsylvania State Police Trooper Melinda Bondarenka said in a statement.\n\nOne of the troopers was life-flighted from the scene to a hospital in Morgantown, West Virginia and the other was taken to a hospital via ambulance, NBC station WPXI reported.\n\nBoth were stable and alert, Bondarenka said.\n\nThe probable ambush of cops in Kissimmee reminds us that hate is not confined to one race, or one ideology and that police are the ones on the front lines actually doing battle with the haters. Almost lost in the narrative about the violence in Charlottesville is that two police officers lost their lives when their helicopter crashed. They have become an afterthought to the main stage drama of racists, Nazis, and antifa warring in the streets of an American city.\n\nBetween the violent haters and us stands the \"Thin Blue Line\" of dedicated men and women in law enforcement. Theirs is a thankless, dangerous job made more so by those who wish to kill them to make a political statement. It doesn't matter what color the police officers are - both Kissimmee officers were black. They were targets of violent extremists who wish to make their jobs impossible to carry out.\n\nNo doubt, there are many police officers and sheriff's deputies going to work today wondering if they {"id": "10050992", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711879714", "source": {"id": "726", "title": "SunSentinel", "uri": "sun-sentinel.com"}, "url": "http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/os-kissimmee-police-shot-20170818-story.html", "body": "One officer was shot and killed and another was gravely injured Friday night in what the Kissimmee Police chief said might have been an ambush in McLaren Circle.\n\nPolice Chief Jeff O'Dell reported Officer Matthew Baxter was killed and Sgt. Sam Howard was shot and is in grave condition. The uniformed officers were responding to a call at 9:30 p.m. in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets.\n\n\"It breaks my heart to have to come speak to you tonight about another senseless tragedy,\" O'Dell said.\n\nAt least two people were taken into custody and police were searching for a third suspect.\n\nWhen asked about whether the officers were ambushed, O'Dell said it was too early to say, but it was \"leading toward that.\"\n\nHe said both officers were husbands and fathers.\n\n\"This is a tough time for each and every one of us,\" O'Dell said.\n\nHoward was a 10-year veteran of the department and Baxter had been with the Kissimmee department for three years.\n\nOsceola County Commissioner Fred Hawkins Jr. said he couldn't believe the news.\n\n\"It's just awful. We're praying for the families of these officers and for the whole KPD family,\" he said.\n\nThe last officer killed on the job was in 1983 after being shot.\n\nInformation about those in custody was not immediately provided.\n\nCarlos Santiago, 37, was driving with his wife and daughter back from dinner on International Drive when they saw dozens of patrol cars speed past them on Orange Blossom Trail.\n\n\"They were just flying,\" he said. \"It was pretty obvious something bad had happened.\"\n\nThe area where the shooting happened is in McLaren Circle.\n\n\"It's fairly well known as not a great area. It's pretty run down compared to the rest of the city and it's known for having more crime,\" Santiago said.\n\nFHP said there was \"heavy police activity\" in the area and told people to avoid the area. There was also a large police presence at Roscoe's late Friday.\n\nWhile the media waited for O'Dell to address the public in front of the emergency entrance at Osceola Regional Medical Center, two women were being escorted out of the building by two police officers. They were both crying and huddled before they saw the lights and cameras outside and dashed back into the building.\n\nAt least four Osceola deputies were stationed by the south entrance to the hospital, wearing body armor and carrying heavy guns, standing next to their patrol cars.\n\nAlexis Nieves, 27, was driving to see a friend when she got stopped at a red light on Orange Blossom Trail and U.S. Highway 192.\n\nShe saw a few cop cars then dozens started arriving to the intersection. She looked to her left and saw an officer with a long gun, the she saw a person being loaded into an ambulance. There were helicopters circling the in the area.\n\nEmergency crews were doing CPR and trying to resuscitate the person. Nieves didn't know it was an officer who had been shot.\n\n\"I just started crying,\" she said. \"I didn't know what to think. It's so sad.\"\n\nNieves said she saw said more than 80 law enforcement vehicles flooding the area, along with fire trucks and EMS vehicles.\n\n\"I was in the middle of it all and couldn't believe what was happening,\" she said. \"I called my friend in tears. I've never seen anything like that.\"\n\nMessages of support flowed out from across the country.\n\nOn its Twitter account, the Orlando Police Department said, \"Please keep @kissimmeepolice in your prayers tonight.\"\n\nThe Orange County Sheriff's Office also offered its own message of comfort, saying, \"Our solidarity is with @kissimmeepolice as they deal with this tragic loss.\"\n\nKissimmee Police has 104 officers. O'Dell took over the department in August 2016.\n\nOn Friday night, there was also a report from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office that two police officers had been shot on the Westside of Jacksonville. Two Pennsylvania Troopers were also reported shot late Friday.\n\nThe shootings received nationwide attention, with President Donald Trump sending thoughts and prayers to the Kissimmee Police.\n\nIt has been a dangerous year for law enforcement in Central Florida. Lt. Debra Clayton, a 17-year veteran of the Orlando Police Department, was killed in a gunfight in the Wal-Mart parking lot while attempting to arrest Markeith Loyd, a suspect in the murder of his pregnant ex-girlfriend, Sade Dixon. Loyd was later captured after a nine-day manhunt.\n\nOrange County Sheriff's Deputy Norman Lewis, a motorcycle officer, was also killed that day during the pursuit for Loyd.\n\nEarlier reports Friday night from official sources indicated that two officers had died.\n\nStaff Writers Bianca Padro Ocasio, Christal Hayes, Krista Torralva and Gal Tziperman Lotan contributed to this report.\n\njareddick@orlandosentinel.com, 407-420-5268 or Twitter @jbreddick\n\nRead more about this story in our e-edition at OrlandoSentinel.com/late or on our website.\n\nInteractive map: Every Howard, 36, died from his injuries on Saturday afternoon, Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference.\n\nWith the help of surveillance video, police arrested Everett Miller, 45, at a bar around 11:30 p.m. Miller, who was carrying 9 mm handgun and revolver when arrested, was charged with first-degree murder for the death of Baxter, O'Dell said.\n\nMiller is expected to also be charged with Howard's murder, said Kissimmee police spokeswoman Stacie Miller.\n\n\"Let me be very clear - last night's violence against our law enforcement community is reprehensible and has no place in our state,\" Florida Governor Rick Scott said in a statement. \"Florida has zero tolerance for violence and we will not accept hatred for one second.\" President Donald Trump sent his condolences in a Twitter message: \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones,\" he said.\n\nIn a second, unrelated shooting, officers in Jacksonville came under fire as they walked toward a house where a man with a high-powered rifle was threatening three people inside, Mike Bruno, director of the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office, told reporters.\n\nThe man opened fire through the door, then exited and exchanged gunfire with the officers, wounding two of them, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect, Derrick Brabham, 25, had no criminal history and was fatally shot in the gunfight, Williams said.\n\nIn a third shooting, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect at a market in Fairchance, 60 miles (100 km) south of Pittsburgh, local media reported.\n\nThe suspect died, according to Pittsburgh television station WPXI, which cited unnamed police sources. The two state troopers were in stable condition, according to local media.\n\n(Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles and Gina Cherelus in New York; Editing by Mary Milliken and Lisa Shumaker)", The police officer, who was fatally shot, was responding to a suspicious activity call with a colleague before being caught in gunfire on Friday night in Kissimmee, a city in Virginia, Xinhua news agency reported. The shooting may have been an ambush, and the pair of police officers did not have an opportunity to return fire, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell told a press conference early on Saturday. \"Officers immediately responded to the area and found two of their fallen brothers gravely injured on the roadway,\" O'Dell said.\n\nOne of them was later pronounced dead, while the other remains hospitalized. O'Dell said they were not wearing body cameras at the time of the shooting. The suspect, also wounded by gunshot, died after being taken to a local hospital. A spokeswoman with Pennsylvania State Police said two state troopers were shot and a suspect killed outside a small-town store south of Pittsburgh on Friday night.\n\nLocal reports said one of the injured troopers was air-lifted to hospital and the other was taken to hospital via ambulance. Residents, he said, \"get tired of putting up with some of the drug dealing and nonsense that goes on in the neighborhood.\"\n\nHe added, \"And we're doing our part to try to keep them safe, and then we have this tonight.\"\n\nGov. Rick Scott released a statement in response to the shooting.\n\n\"Today, I join every Floridian to honor these law enforcement officers, their brothers and sisters in uniform, and their families,\" he said. \"My heart breaks for Matthew's family. We are with you!\"\n\nThe Kissimmee shooting was the first of two attacks on Florida police officers Friday night. Two sheriff's officers in Jacksonville were wounded when responding to a suicide call, officials said.\n\nThe officers were shot around 11 p.m. on the city's west side as they responded to a call about an attempted suicide, said Mike Bruno, director of the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office. The officers' names were not released; one was said to be in critical condition and one in stable condition.\n\nWhen officers arrived at the scene of the reported suicide attempt, they were confronted by a man with a rifle, while three people hid in a back bedroom, Mr. Bruno said. In the ensuing gunfire, one of the officers was shot in the hands and one in the stomach.\n\nThe gunman was killed, according to the Sheriff's Office. The three people hiding in the bedroom were not injured, Mr. Bruno said.\n\nA police shooting was also reported Friday night in Fairchance, Pa., where two State Police troopers were shot in their car in a supermarket shopping center, according to ABC News and WXPI-TV in Pittsburgh.\n\nThe troopers, who were not identified, were in stable condition, with one airlifted to a hospital in Morgantown, {"id": "10034546", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 361, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 362, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "711833947", "source": {"id": "228", "title": "yahoo.com", "uri": "yahoo.com"}, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/florida-officer-killed-one-several-shootings-law-enforcement-080125370.html", "body": "By Alex Dobuzinskis\n\n(Reuters) - Six U.S. police officers were shot and one was killed in three separate encounters with suspects in Florida and Pennsylvania on Friday, and two suspects in those shootings also died, according to officials and local media.\n\nOfficials did not say there was any connection between the three shootings.\n\nIn Kissimmee, a community south of Orlando, Florida, two officers came under fire after approaching a group of people based on suspicions they might be involved in illegal conduct, Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell told reporters.\n\nThe two officers, who were in uniform, appear to have been taken by surprise when they came under fire, he added. Police later arrested a suspect, whose name was not released.\n\nThe two officers were rushed to a hospital but one of the men, Officer Matthew Baxter, died of his injuries.\n\n\"Tonight we lost a brave officer - Matthew Baxter. Husband/father/hero,\" Florida Governor Rick Scott said on Twitter.\n\nThe other officer, Sergeant Sam Howard, was in \"grave, critical condition and the prognosis does not look good,\" O'Dell said.\n\nThe neighborhood where the shooting occurred has a problem with drug dealing, O'Dell said, and before the shooting the two officers approached the group of people to ask them questions.\n\nAside from the main suspect, police took two people at the scene into custody for questioning, he said.\n\nPresident Donald Trump said in a statement on Twitter, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones.\"\n\nIn another shooting in Jacksonville, Florida, a group of officers came under fire as they walked toward a house where a man with a high-powered rifle was threatening three people inside, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno told reporters.\n\nThe man opened fire through the door, then exited and exchanged gunfire with the officers from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office, wounding one officer in the hands and another officer in the stomach, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect, whose name was not released, was fatally shot in the gunfight, police said, and one officer was hospitalized in critical condition while the other was listed as stable.\n\nIn a third shooting, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect at a market in Fairchance, Pennsylvania, according to local media.\n\nThe suspect died, according to Pittsburgh television station WPXI, which cited unnamed police sources. The two state troopers were in stable condition, according to local media.\n\n(Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles; Editing by Toby Chopra)", "dateTime": "2017-08-19T08:48:00Z", {"id": "10105719", "categories": [{"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712030337", "source": {"id": "1454", "title": "Punch Newspapers", "uri": "punchng.com"}, "url": "http://punchng.com/six-policemen-shot-the-same-night-two-fatally/", "body": "Six US police officers were shot in one night in the states of Florida and Pennsylvania, two fatally, prompting President Donald Trump to tweet his support for the slain officers' department early Saturday.\n\nIn the central Florida city of Kissimmee -- close to the Walt Disney World Resort and other amusement parks -- Officer Matthew Baxter died shortly after a shooting Friday; his colleague, Sergeant Richard \"Sam\" Howard, died of his wounds on Saturday, the police department announced on Twitter.\n\nThe officers had been checking on suspicious people in an area known for drug activity around 9:30 pm Friday (0130 GMT Saturday). Five minutes later, authorities received a call that officers had been shot.\n\nFirst responders found the officers \"gravely wounded\" in the road, O'Dell said.\n\nA suspect, identified by police as Everett Miller, was arrested.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump, a staunch supporter of US law enforcement, tweeted early Saturday.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, sheriff's officers responding to an attempted suicide call late Friday were confronted by a suspect firing a high-powered rifle, Director Mike Bruno told a news conference.\n\nTwo officers were shot in an exchange of gunfire, one hit in both hands and the other in the stomach, Bruno said. The suspect was killed. The officers were both in stable condition Saturday, the website of the Florida Times-Union reported.\n\nAnd two Pennsylvania state troopers were shot Friday night, the agency said.\n\n\"Two state troopers shot and [the] suspect is deceased,\" Pennsylvania State Police spokeswoman Melinda Bondarenka told ABC News. \"We are not releasing any more details at this time.\"\n\nBoth troopers are expected to survive, ABC said of the shooting in the community of Fairchance, about 60 miles (97 kilometers) south of Pittsburgh. (AP) -- A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Florida and the grave wounding of another officer was arrested several hours after the attack in a bar, authorities said Saturday.\n\nEverett Miller faces a charge of first-degree murder for the killing of Officer Matthew Baxter and could face other charges for the wounding of Officer Sam Howard, said Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell at a news conference Saturday.\n\nUPDATE: Heartbroken to hear loss of @kissimmeepolice officer Matthew Baxter. Praying for a quick recovery for officer in critical condition. https://t.co/BYhUFOe1CJ -- Rick Scott (@FLGovScott)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nDuring a patrol of the neighborhood south of Orlando's theme park hub late Friday, the officers got into a scuffle with Miller, who shot them, the police chief said.\n\nThe officers didn't have an opportunity to return fire.\n\nSheriff's deputies with a neighboring law enforcement agency later tracked Miller down to a bar and approached him. Miller started reaching toward his waistband when the deputies tackled and subdued him, O'Dell said.\n\nThe found a handgun and revolver on him.\n\n\"They were extremely brave and heroic actions taken by the deputies,\" O'Dell said.\n\n\"We've got to come together as a nation and get our community involved\" says Chief O'Dell when asked about nationwide violence against LEOs. -- Kissimmee Police (@kissimmeepolice)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nThe police chief said Miller would be taken to jail wearing the fallen officer's handcuffs.\n\nAuthorities originally said they believed there were four suspects, but the chief said Saturday that no other arrests are anticipated.\n\nSeparately, other two officers were injured late Friday in Jacksonville, Florida, after police responded to reports of an attempted suicide at a home where three other people were thought to be in danger. {"id": "10113796", "categories": [{"id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 203, "label": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law Enforcement", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Law/Law_Enforcement", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 336, "label": "dmoz/Shopping/Office Products/Furniture", "uri": "dmoz/Shopping/Office_Products/Furniture", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712057874", "source": {"id": "2725", "title": "Bradenton Herald", "uri": "bradenton.com"}, "url": "http://www.bradenton.com/news/local/crime/article168166177.html", "body": "Sgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard died Saturday afternoon after being gravely wounded in a shootout with a suspect Friday night.\n\nIn all, six law enforcement officers were shot Friday night in American cities: two Kissimmee police officers, two Jacksonville County Sheriff's Office deputies and two Pennsylvania State Police officers.\n\nKissimmee Police officer Matthew Baxter was shot and killed, Chief of Police Jeff O'Dell first announced during a news conference shortly after midnight on Saturday. The second officer, Howard, was in \"grave, critical\" condition at Osceola Regional Hospital on Saturday but later passed away.\n\n\"Both are husbands. Both are fathers,\" O'Dell said.\n\nOvernight, police were able to identify the suspected shooter, Everette Glenn Miller, who has since been arrested, O'Dell announced during another news conference at 9 a.m. Saturday. Miller, 45, was charged with murder, carrying a concealed weapon and resisting arrest.\n\nOsceola County Sheriff's Office detectives found Miller at 11:30 p.m. Friday, at Roscoe's Bar & Packaging, 2344 N Orange Blossom Trail, Kissimmee, the chief said.\n\n\"We had a small snipette of video that placed the suspect at the scene at the time of the stop,\" O'Dell said.\n\nMiller reached toward his waistband as detectives approached him, but they were able to tackle him to the ground and arrest him. Miller had a 9 mm handgun and .22 caliber revolver at the time he was arrested.\n\nBaxter, 27, was married to a fellow Kissimmee police officer and had four children. Howard is married with one child.\n\n\"It's a tough time in law enforcement,\" Chief O'Dell says. \"It's getting tough ... these senseless acts are going on.\"\n\nIn Jacksonville, two sheriff's office police officers were shot when responding to a report of an attempted suicide, sheriff's office Director Mike Bruno said during a news conference at 1:30 a.m. Saturday.\n\nKevin Jarrell, a 5-year veteran, was shot in the stomach but was expected to recover, Sheriff Mike Williams said during another news conference Saturday. Michael Fox, an 11-year-veteran, was shot in both his hands and had undergone surgery on Saturday, but was also expected to recover.\n\nBoth officers were listed in stable condition on Saturday.\n\nThe suspect, later identified as Derrick Brabham, 25, had been drinking all night which led to arguments which later led to threats to hurt himself and others in the home. Three women; Brabham's girlfriend, the girlfriend's mother and a family friend, were hiding in a bathroom.\n\nWhen officers arrived, the seven formed a contact team before approaching during which time they saw Brabham and one of the women outside arguing. When the couple reentered the home, the officers heard gunfire.\n\nWhen Gerald and Fox entered the home, the sheriff said, the suspect immediately opened fire on them at close range. The officers returned fire, shooting the suspect twice. Three more officers entered home, taking away their injured fellow officers and then returning to look for the suspect.\n\nThe suspect was found in the hallway, Williams said. The three women were then found as well as Brabham and his girlfriend's 19-month-old baby. The baby had been away from shooting in another room.\n\nBrabham, had no criminal history, the sheriff said. He had been armed with a semi-automatic .223 caliber riffle\n\n\"We often talk about the inherent dangers of police work. Tonight those dangers were all too real for these officers,\" Bruno said. \"As the officers approached the house, they knew it was a rifle the individual was shooting. They knew they were staring danger in the face and yet they moved forward to meet their commitment they held and that they swore to take for this community.\"\n\nTwo Pennsylvania state troopers were shot just after 8 p.m. Friday in the Fairchance Borough of Fayette County, Pa., according to the state police department. The troopers, assigned to the Criminal Investigation Division, had arranged a meeting with a suspect, Clarence Belsar.\n\nBelsar, 26, was suspected of selling property stolen in recent burglaries in the area, police posted Saturday morning on Facebook. When the Pennsylvania troopers approached him, he began to walk away and ignored their commands. When they attempted to stop Belsar, a struggle ensued.\n\nBelsar pulled a handgun and fired one shot, which struck both troopers, police said. The troopers returned fire, shooting Belsar dead.\n\nOne trooper was shot in the hand, treated in a hospital and later released. Five minutes later, authorities received a call that officers had been shot.\n\nFirst responders found the officers \"gravely wounded\" in the road, O'Dell said.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" President Trump, a staunch supporter of US law enforcement, tweeted early Saturday.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, sheriff's officers responding to an attempted suicide call late Friday were confronted by a suspect firing a high-powered rifle, Director Mike Bruno told a news conference.\n\nTwo officers were shot in the exchange of gunfire, one hit in both hands and the other in the stomach, Mr Bruno said. Police later arrested a suspect, whose name has not been released.\n\nThe two officers were rushed to a hospital but Officer Matthew Baxter died of his injuries. The other officer, Sergeant Sam Howard, was in \"grave, critical condition and the prognosis does not look good,\" the chief said.\n\nThe neighborhood where the shooting occurred has a problem with drug dealing, O'Dell said, and before the shooting the two officers approached the group of people to ask them questions.\n\nAside from the main suspect, police took two other people who were at the scene into custody to question them, he said.\n\nPresident Donald Trump said in a statement on Twitter, \"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones.\"\n\nIn another shooting in Jacksonville, Florida, a group of officers came under fire as they walked toward a house where a man with a high-powered rifle was threatening three people in the home, Jacksonville Sheriff's Office Director Mike Bruno told reporters.\n\nThe man opened fire through the door and then exited and exchanged gunfire with the officers from the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office, Bruno said, wounding one officer in the hands and another officer in the stomach.\n\nThe suspect, whose name was not released, was fatally shot in the exchange of gunfire, police said, and one officer was hospitalized in critical condition while the other one was listed as stable.\n\nIn a third shooting, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect at a market in Fairchance, Pennsylvania, according to local media.\n\nThe suspect died, according to Pittsburgh television station WPXI, which cited unnamed police sources. Six police officers were shot, one of them fatally, in three separate, apparently unrelated encounters with suspects in Florida and Pennsylvania on Friday, and two suspects in the shootings also died, officials and local media said on Saturday.\n\nIn Kissimmee, south of Orlando, Florida, two uniformed officers came under fire after approaching a group of people in a neighborhood where drug dealing is a problem, Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said at a news conference.\n\nOfficer Matthew Baxter, 27, was killed, while Sergeant Sam Howard was in \"grave, critical condition and the prognosis does not look good,\" O'Dell said.\n\nRELATED: Poteau police officer adopts child after investigating his case of severe child abuse\n\nA suspect, identified as Everett Miller, 46, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder in the shooting death, O'Dell said.\n\n\"Let me be very clear - last night's violence against our law enforcement community is reprehensible and has no place in our state,\" Florida Governor Rick Scott said in a statement. \"Florida has zero-tolerance for violence and we will not accept hatred for one second.\"\n\nIn a shooting in Jacksonville, Florida, officers came under fire as they walked toward a house where a man with a high-powered rifle was threatening three people inside, Mike Bruno, director of the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office, told reporters.\n\nThe man opened fire through the door, then exited and exchanged gunfire with the officers, wounding two of them, Bruno said.\n\nThe suspect, Derrick Brabham, 25, had no criminal history and was fatally shot in the gunfight, Williams said.\n\nIn a third shooting, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect at a market in Fairchance, 60 miles south of Pittsburgh, local media reported.\n\nThe suspect died, according to Pittsburgh television station WPXI, which cited unnamed police sources. The two state troopers were in stable condition, according to local media.\n\n(Reporting by Alex Dobuzinskis in Los Angeles and Gina Cherelus in New York; Editing by Toby Chopra and Mary Milliken)", Five minutes later, authorities received a call that officers had been shot.\n\nPolice chief resigns, US protesters confront mayor in Australian's slaying\n\nFirst responders found the officers \"gravely wounded\" in the road, O'Dell said.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump, a staunch supporter of US law enforcement, tweeted early Saturday.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, sheriff's officers responding to an attempted suicide call late Friday were confronted by a suspect firing a high-powered rifle, Director Mike Bruno told a news conference.\n\nTwo officers were shot in the exchange of gunfire, one hit in both hands and the other in the stomach, Bruno said. The suspect was killed.\n\nAnd two Pennsylvania state troopers were shot Friday night, the agency said.\n\n\"Two state troopers shot and [the] suspect is deceased,\" Pennsylvania State Police spokeswoman Melinda Bondarenka told ABC News. \"We are not releasing any more details at this time.\"\n\nBoth troopers are expected to survive, ABC said of the shooting in the community of Fairchance, We also learned that two state troopers were shot in Pennsylvania as well.\"\n\n\"Unfortunately, a member of the Kissimmee Police Department lost his life. Kissimmee Police Department Officer Matthew Baxter was a married father of three and a dedicated law enforcement hero in Central Florida. The violence last night also left another member of the Kissimmee Police Department, Sgt. Sam Howard, in grave condition. We are praying for his recovery and the recovery of all law enforcement injured last night, including the two officers from the Jacksonville Police Department.\"\n\n\"Let me be very clear - last night's violence against our law enforcement community is reprehensible and has no place in our state. Florida has zero tolerance for violence and we will not accept hatred for one second. In Florida, justice is swiftly served against anyone who attacks our law enforcement officers.\"\n\n\"Today, I join every Floridian to honor these law enforcement officers, their brothers and sisters in uniform, and their families. My heart breaks for Matthew's family. May Matthew's service and the service of our law enforcement community be a constant reminder of the sacrifice of those who serve to keep us safe. Following last night's shootings I have been in touch with local law enforcement and community officials to let them know that our state supports them every step of the way.\"\n\n\"The best thing about Florida is the people who live here. One of those officers died and the other is clinging to life.\n\nKissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell announced that Everett Glenn Miller, 45, was taken into custody last night and is charged with first degree premeditated murder. Miller used to live in the Tampa Bay area. He has past addresses in Tampa, Riverview and Dover.\n\nMiller is accused of shooting Officer Sam Howard, a 10-year veteran of the force, and Officer Matthew Baxter, a 3-year-veteran. The officers had been called to check out a report of suspicious persons in the area of Palmway and Cypress streets, police said.\n\nAbout a half hour later, a 911 caller reported the officers were shot. Rescuers arrived, and the officers were taken to a hospital.\n\nBaxter died, Howard is in critical condition, and his outlook is grave.\n\nO'Dell says the officers apparently were caught by surprise and not able to return fire.\n\nA couple hours after the shooting, police located Miller and when they confronted him, they say he reached for his waistband. That's when the officer tackled him and took him into custody. Miller reportedly had two weapons on him.\n\nMiller was transported to jail in Officer Baxter's handcuffs.\n\nOur solidarity is with @kissimmeepolice as they deal with this tragic loss. -- OCSO FL News (@OrangeCoSheriff)\n\nAugust 19, 2017\n\nPresident Donald Trump tweeted about the shooting early Saturday.\n\nMy thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. Five minutes later, authorities received a call that officers had been shot.\n\nFirst responders found the officers \"gravely wounded\" in the road, O'Dell said.\n\n\"My thoughts and prayers are with the @KissimmeePolice and their loved ones. We are with you!\" Trump, a staunch supporter of US law enforcement, tweeted early today.\n\nIn the northern Florida city of Jacksonville, sheriff's officers responding to an attempted suicide call late Friday were confronted by a suspect firing a high-powered rifle, Director Mike Bruno told a news conference.\n\nTwo officers were shot in the exchange of gunfire, one hit in both hands and the other in the stomach, Bruno said. Sam Howard in Florida.\n\nThe 45-year-old, who left the Marines for mental health reasons, came in contact with police around 9:30 p.m and shot at officers, killing Baxter and Howard.\n\nKissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell said that there was a brief struggle before gunfire ensued, the New York Daily News reports.\n\nMiller managed to flee the scene, but officers caught up with him at around 11:30 p.m. in a bar. Upon searching him, officers discovered a 9-millimeter handgun and a .22 caliber revolver.\n\nHe was taken to jail in Officer Baxter's handcuffs.\n\n\"I am so proud of the sworn and civilian members of our department by acting quickly to identify the suspect and bring him to justice,\" said O'Dell in a statement. \"We will mourn over the next few day; we will get through this and we love them for what they do.\"\n\nRELATED: Police are searching for answers after a high school teacher shot himself in his classroom\n\nFour suspects were wanted for the shooting, but O'Dell said that he is not expecting any more arrests. [sic] I have to reinforce my castle. Send gold & iron.\"\n\nThat night, Miller, 45, carried two guns -- a 9mm and .22 revolver, police said.\n\nHe was with two other people near Palmway and Cypress streets when Kissimmee police Officer Matthew Baxter approached them to investigate a report of suspicious people.\n\nPolice have released few details about what happened next. But a \"scuffle\" broke out, according to Kissimmee Police Chief Jeff O'Dell, and it ended with both Baxter and Sgt. Richard \"Sam\" Howard, who came to help him, shot.\n\nOsceola County Sheriff's detectives found Miller about two hours later at Roscoe's Bar & Packaging on Orange Blossom Trail.\n\nMiller is now in the Osceola County Jail facing charges of first-degree murder, resisting arrest without violence, and illegally carrying a concealed weapon.\n\nThe other two people were questioned but not arrested, police said.\n\nMiller enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps in 1989, Department of Defense records show. He left active duty on July 27, 2010.\n\nHe had no criminal record in Florida, Florida Department of Law Enforcement records show, and three minor traffic tickets in Osceola In the third incident, two Pennsylvania State Police troopers were wounded and a suspect killed in an exchange of fire at a market in Fairchance.
